column3: Research_direction

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cancer biology, pancreatic cancer, colorectal cancer, Notch signaling, KEAP1-NRF2 pathway, E3 ubiquitin ligases, metabolic adaptations in cancer, and therapeutic strategies. 

In cancer biology, the researcher explores various pathways and mechanisms involved in tumor initiation and progression, focusing on the KEAP1-NRF2 pathway, which is crucial in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and pancreatic cancer. The role of Notch4 in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) is examined, revealing its upregulation and impact on tumorigenesis. The researcher also investigates colorectal cancer (CRC), highlighting distinct epigenetic landscapes and the role of E3 ubiquitin ligase Mule in regulating intestinal stem cell proliferation. Metabolic adaptations in cancer are studied, particularly in PDAC, where mitochondrial respiration proteins are linked to metastasis. Therapeutic strategies include the development of novel bisphosphonate inhibitors targeting geranylgeranyl pyrophosphate synthase and the potential of high doses of vitamin C to selectively kill mutant CRC cells. Overall, this research emphasizes the interplay between molecular pathways and therapeutic innovations in cancer treatment.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) mutations, immune dysregulation, allergic diseases, genetic variants in immune-related conditions, and therapeutic strategies for immunodeficiencies.

Research on STAT mutations reveals their distinct clinical implications, such as germline STAT3 gain-of-function mutations leading to lymphoproliferation and autoimmunity, while loss-of-function mutations result in Hyper-IgE syndrome. Immune dysregulation studies highlight the roles of immune cells in allergic and infectious diseases, focusing on TH9 cells and their activation pathways. The exploration of PLCG2-associated immune dysregulation (PLAID) examines the clinical presentations and unique immune responses caused by PLCG2 mutations. Additionally, research on genetic variants in immune-related conditions identifies links between specific mutations and disorders, including JAK1 variants associated with autoimmunity and TRAF3 mutations leading to immune dysregulation. Finally, the development of therapeutic strategies for immunodeficiencies emphasizes the need for targeted treatments based on genetic findings, as well as the interplay between genetic mutations and environmental factors in allergic diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pediatric critical care, genetic testing, pediatric neurocritical care, neurogenesis, traumatic brain injury (TBI), neurodegenerative diseases, inflammatory responses, and blood-brain barrier (BBB) dynamics. 

Pediatric critical care focuses on management strategies for critically ill children, emphasizing the role of genetic testing in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU). The research highlights the impact of primary care teams on patient outcomes and the challenges of hybrid care models during the COVID-19 pandemic. Neurocritical care advancements aim to improve functional outcomes in pediatric patients. Neurogenesis research investigates the role of microglia and ApoE in adult neurogenesis, particularly following TBI, where ApoE is crucial for cognitive recovery. TBI studies reveal cognitive impairments and potential therapeutic targets like Cdk5, while exploring the link between TBI and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's. Inflammatory responses, particularly related to COVID-19 and perinatal hypoxia, are examined for their effects on neurodevelopment and immune responses. Lastly, the dynamics of BBB opening through focused ultrasound and its implications for neurodegenerative disease therapies are explored, highlighting the role of brain macrophages in this process.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: auditory processing, speech perception, neural mechanisms, auditory attention decoding, brain-computer interfaces (BCI), neural speech recognition, and deep neural networks (DNNs). 

Auditory processing focuses on how the auditory cortex encodes linguistic features and manages sound in noisy environments, revealing hierarchical processing and distinct areas for phonetic and higher-level features. Speech perception research investigates neural mechanisms involved in distinguishing speech in multi-talker scenarios, highlighting the role of the auditory cortex and attentional modulation. Auditory attention decoding explores improved techniques for identifying target speakers amidst background noise, utilizing self-supervised learning and brain activity data. Brain-computer interfaces research includes developing practical courses to equip students with skills in EEG-based systems, enhancing understanding of BCI applications. Neural speech recognition aims to create systems for continuous phoneme decoding using neural activity data. Lastly, deep neural networks are employed to model nonlinear stimulus-response mappings in sensory circuits, providing insights into neural responses and enhancing accuracy in predicting auditory processing outcomes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: epilepsy, sleep neuroscience, neurotechnology, memory processes, neuroethics, bioelectronics, and pediatric neurology. 

Epilepsy research focuses on understanding epileptic encephalopathy in children, examining how abnormal activity disrupts brain development and cognitive functions. The interaction between interictal epileptiform discharges (IEDs) and sleep spindles is explored, revealing their impact on cognitive deficits and surgical outcomes. Sleep neuroscience investigates the effects of sleep states on seizure timing and neural activity, challenging existing models of sleep homeostasis. Neurotechnology encompasses closed-loop neurostimulation and organic neural interfaces, aiming to manipulate cognitive processes and record brain activity non-invasively. Memory processes research emphasizes the role of hippocampal-cortical coupling in memory consolidation and the influence of noradrenergic signaling on synaptic potentiation. Neuroethics integrates societal implications of neurotechnology into engineering practices. Bioelectronics focuses on developing advanced devices for in vivo electrophysiology, enhancing the recording of neural signals and understanding neurological disorders. Finally, pediatric neurology addresses challenges in language mapping during epilepsy surgery and the phenotypic variability in conditions like Krabbe disease, emphasizing timely diagnosis and treatment.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: ginger metabolites, airway smooth muscle (ASM) relaxation, asthma treatment, diacylglycerol kinase (DGK), COVID-19 management, intubation protocols, personal protective equipment (PPE), host-microbiota relationship, perioperative care, and critical illness. 

The investigation into ginger metabolites focuses on their potential therapeutic effects on ASM relaxation, particularly in asthma treatment, highlighting 6-shogaol's role in inhibiting phosphodiesterases and promoting relaxation in human ASM. The role of DGK in regulating ASM contraction is explored as a therapeutic target for asthma, emphasizing its ability to modulate diacylglycerol levels to prevent excessive contraction. In the context of COVID-19, the researcher has contributed to understanding the disease's impact on critical care resources and developed guidelines for airway management and PPE use during intubation to protect healthcare workers. Additionally, the research examines the host-microbiota relationship, particularly how stress from surgery or illness can disrupt microbiota, suggesting interventions to enhance recovery in perioperative and critical care settings.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: transcription factors, energy balance regulation, neuronal differentiation, genetic regulation, obesity, gene expression profiling, CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing, neurodegenerative disorders, single-cell genomics, and hypothalamic neuron function.

Transcription factors, specifically T-box 3 (Tbx3), play a crucial role in hypothalamic neurons that regulate energy balance through neuropeptide release, affecting metabolic processes. The research emphasizes Tbx3's importance in maintaining neuron identity and plasticity, linking it to body weight regulation in both Drosophila and human embryonic stem cells. Energy balance regulation is further explored through the creation of a chromatin architecture atlas, connecting gene regulation to complex traits like obesity and reproductive timing. Genetic regulation is highlighted in studies of Bardet-Biedl syndrome, revealing how mutations impact insulin signaling and energy homeostasis. Gene expression profiling in various brain regions uncovers localized expression patterns of obesity-associated genes, contributing to obesity's pathophysiology. CRISPR/Cas9 genome editing research enhances efficiency for non-coding DNA. The investigation of neurodegenerative disorders emphasizes the potential of patient-derived neuron models. Lastly, single-cell genomics provides insights into the developmental trajectories of hypothalamic neuronal diversity, revealing distinct subtypes and their maturation drivers.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT) disease, neurofilament proteins, cytoskeletal proteins, spectrin superfamily, neuronal intermediate filaments, microtubule-actin cross-linking factors, and linker proteins. 

Research on Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, particularly CMT2E, investigates the genetic mutations affecting neurofilament light polypeptide (NEFL) and their impact on neuronal structures using knock-in mouse models. The studies reveal abnormal neurofilament inclusions and altered neuronal processes, enhancing understanding of CMT pathophysiology. The neurofilament proteins, specifically _-internexin and peripherin, are explored for their roles in neuronal inclusion diseases and ALS, respectively. The spectrin superfamily is examined for its role in connecting cytoskeletal elements to cellular structures, with a focus on protein interactions and disease implications. Additionally, microtubule-actin cross-linking factors like MACF1 are studied for their significance in cell migration and development. Finally, linker proteins such as APC are highlighted for their roles in integrating cytoskeletal networks and influencing cell behavior, emphasizing their importance beyond mere structural support.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: calcineurin signaling, germ cell tumors, Down syndrome and leukemia, gastric organoids, cancer stem cells, tumor angiogenesis, and biomarkers in cancer. Calcineurin signaling research focuses on the threshold pattern of gene expression influenced by calcipressin, which is crucial for immune and neuronal processes. In germ cell tumors, the study of seminomas reveals their resemblance to primordial germ cells and highlights genetic mechanisms involved in tumorigenesis. The intersection of Down syndrome and leukemia explores genetic factors linking trisomy 21 to increased leukemia risk, emphasizing ongoing challenges in treatment and understanding of leukemogenesis. Gastric organoids are utilized to develop standardized methods for studying gastric biology and predicting chemotherapy responses in gastric cancer. Research on cancer stem cells investigates KRAS activation's role in tumor angiogenesis and metastasis, alongside the implications of various genetic mutations on tumor behavior. Lastly, the identification of potential serum biomarkers in dogs contributes to the broader understanding of cancer diagnostics.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neuroscience, behavioral biology, sensory processing, machine learning, and developmental biology. 

In neuroscience, the researcher investigates neural activity in Drosophila and mice, focusing on the spatial and temporal structure of neuronal responses during various behaviors. Behavioral biology is explored through studies on Drosophila's egg-laying behavior and the influence of pheromones like darcin in mice on mating behaviors. Sensory processing is examined in Drosophila's bitter-sensing neurons and the role of olfactory circuits in cognitive mapping, with insights into synaptic plasticity and decision-making processes. Machine learning is applied to replicate anatomical connectivity in olfactory circuits and to automate signal quantification in neural activity studies. Developmental biology is highlighted through the study of the dwarf cuttlefish, including its brain atlas and rapid embryonic development, emphasizing its unique neural functions and evolutionary adaptations. Overall, the research integrates these fields to enhance understanding of neural mechanisms underlying behavior and sensory processing across different species.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: transplantation, T cell dynamics, sarcoma management, liver resection techniques, and hemostatic agents. Transplantation research focuses on strategies to improve allograft tolerance, including the temporary transplantation of donor spleens and the role of graft-versus-host responses in promoting mixed chimerism. T cell dynamics studies the behavior of alloreactive T cell clones in the gut and their transition during transplant rejection, as well as the distribution of T cell subsets in lymphoid and mucosal tissues, highlighting early-life immune responses. In sarcoma management, the emphasis is on surgical resection, radiation therapy, and emerging adjunct therapies to improve local control and reduce recurrence rates. The exploration of ex vivo liver resection techniques for unresectable tumors showcases innovative surgical approaches that aim for R0 resection while addressing nutritional challenges post-surgery. Lastly, research on hemostatic agents evaluates the efficacy of Fibrin Sealant Patch versus Oxidized Regenerated Cellulose Patch in managing bleeding during hepatic resection, contributing to improved surgical outcomes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: epigenetics, histone dynamics, DNA replication, antibiotic resistance, neurobiology, cognitive decline, reproductive health, cancer biology, microbiome studies, and cryopreservation techniques.

Epigenetics focuses on mechanisms of inheritance and histone dynamics during DNA replication, emphasizing the role of histone chaperones and complexes in maintaining genome stability. Histone dynamics research investigates the transfer and segregation of parental histones, crucial for epigenetic memory. Antibiotic resistance studies reveal the prevalence of resistance genes in agricultural soils and their implications for public health. Neurobiology research explores brain network alterations in depression and cognitive decline, linking these changes to emotional processing and pain sensitivity. Reproductive health studies assess the impact of genetic factors on infertility and the effectiveness of various IVF protocols. Cancer biology research identifies potential therapeutic targets and mechanisms in glioma and cardiomyopathy. Microbiome studies examine the gut's role in mental health, while cryopreservation techniques evaluate the protective effects of melatonin on oocytes. Overall, this research spans critical areas of health and disease, integrating molecular biology, genetics, and environmental science.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: measles virus (MeV), paramyxovirus fusion mechanisms, antiviral strategies, viral evolution, SARS-CoV-2, Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever, influenza virus, antibody responses in COVID-19, human lung development models, and peptide-membrane interactions. 

MeV research focuses on understanding its pathogenicity, particularly in severe neurological conditions like subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), and exploring neutralizing antibodies targeting viral fusion proteins for therapeutic strategies. Studies on paramyxovirus fusion mechanisms reveal structural insights and potential drug targets through cryo-electron tomography. Antiviral strategies include the development of fusion inhibitors and peptides against various viruses, including SARS-CoV-2 and Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus. Research on viral evolution highlights mutations in immunocompromised hosts that enhance viral persistence. The investigation of SARS-CoV-2 entry intermediates and variants informs the design of entry inhibitors. Additionally, studies on influenza virus inhibition and distinct antibody responses in COVID-19 contribute to understanding viral infections. Lastly, human lung development models and peptide-membrane interactions provide insights into lung disease and antiviral efficacy, respectively.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: gene regulation, chromatin complexes, _-hemoglobinopathy, CRISPR screening, microglia functional genomics, Alzheimer's disease, and induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs). 

Gene regulation is a significant focus, particularly examining the NuRD chromatin complex's role in silencing fetal globins, which has implications for therapies targeting _-hemoglobinopathy. The research employs pooled CRISPR screening to disrupt NuRD protein coding sequences in erythroid precursors, identifying essential subcomplexes for fetal hemoglobin control. The study also investigates the functional roles of specific proteins, such as CHD4, in cell fitness and HbF repression. 

In the realm of microglia functional genomics, the researcher addresses challenges in studying microglia, crucial for brain development and disorders like Alzheimer's disease. The development of an integrated toolkit utilizing human iPSC-derived microglia aims to improve differentiation protocols, characterization, and gene function analysis, thereby enhancing the understanding of microglial roles in neurological disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: mitochondrial biology, psychosocial stress, mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cellular energy metabolism, hair pigmentation, and psychological health. 

Mitochondrial biology is a key focus, examining how psychosocial experiences influence mitochondrial function, particularly oxidative phosphorylation (OxPhos) and morphology under stress. The impact of chronic stress on energy expenditure and aging is also explored, linking mitochondrial dysfunction to various diseases. The role of mtDNA in health is another significant area, with efforts to classify extracellular mtDNA types for better quantification and biomarker potential. The influence of prenatal exposures on mtDNA and its connection to personality traits and immune responses is highlighted. The research further investigates the relationship between stress and hormonal responses, mapping receptor distributions and their effects on hair follicles and pigmentation. The phenomenon of grey hair re-pigmentation in relation to stress relief emphasizes the interplay between mental well-being and physiological changes. Overall, the research underscores the complex interactions between mitochondrial function, stress, and psychological health across various biological systems.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: human pluripotent stem cells, GABAergic neuron migration, epilepsy genetics, Scn8a gene, glutamatergic neurons, sleep regulation, voltage-gated sodium channels, and thalamic-cortical network synchrony. 

The study of human pluripotent stem cells focuses on creating three-dimensional spheroids that replicate the dorsal and ventral forebrain, enabling the investigation of GABAergic neuron migration critical for forebrain development. In epilepsy genetics, the researcher examines the Scn8a gene's role in seizure susceptibility, demonstrating its potential as a therapeutic target through mouse models. The investigation of glutamatergic neurons in the ventrolateral medulla reveals their involvement in sleep regulation, specifically during transitions to NREM sleep. The research on voltage-gated sodium channels introduces a synthetic saxitoxin derivative for precise control of neuronal excitability. Lastly, the exploration of thalamic-cortical network synchrony highlights the effects of Scn8a mutations on seizure phenotypes and attentional flexibility, providing insights into the mechanisms underlying seizure disorders and attention regulation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: natural product isolation, neurobiology, synthetic chemistry, liquid biopsy technology, translational regulation, gene expression, DNA repair mechanisms, therapeutic strategies, microbiota-immune interactions, and immunology.

Natural product isolation focuses on extracting and characterizing hydrolysable gallotannins from Cotinus coggygria, which exhibit anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer properties. Neurobiology research investigates the effects of acute hypoxic shock on rat brain morphology and enzyme activity, particularly the role of tripeptidyl peptidase I in hypoxic stress response. Synthetic chemistry involves the synthesis of 2,5-dihydro-1,2-oxaphospholes through electrophilic cyclization. Liquid biopsy technology advances the capture and characterization of circulating tumor cells (CTCs) for cancer diagnostics, utilizing integrated circuits and nanostructured microelectrodes for efficient identification. Translational regulation studies examine upstream open reading frames (uORFs) in gene expression, highlighting their impact on translation and the role of polyamines. DNA repair mechanisms explore the dynamics of transcription factors and DNA polymerases, while therapeutic strategies include designing small molecules for targeted DNA sequences. Finally, microbiota-immune interactions reveal how dietary factors and intestinal microbiota influence immune responses, emphasizing the role of T cells and macrophages in maintaining mucosal homeostasis.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: AJUBA LIM proteins, Hippo pathway, organ growth regulation, cancer biology, Drosophila wing development, cell proliferation, mechanical signaling. 

AJUBA LIM proteins are a focus of this research, acting as negative regulators of the Hippo pathway, which is essential for controlling organ growth and has significant implications in cancer biology. Their role involves sequestering the Hippo core kinase complex in the cytosol of proliferating mammalian epithelial cells, inhibiting LATS kinase, and thus limiting Hippo regulation of YAP. In contrast, in growth-arrested cells, AJUBA LIM proteins do not interact with or inhibit the Hippo kinase complex. This modulation of Hippo signaling by AJUBA LIM proteins is also correlated with their function in Drosophila wing development. Additionally, the research indicates that AJUBA LIM proteins do not influence YAP activity in response to mechanical signals, highlighting their specific role in reducing Hippo pathway activity during cell proliferation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: viral infections, immune responses, therapeutic strategies, somatosensory neuron subtypes, quorum sensing inhibitors, genetic variability in coronaviruses, health literacy, surgical practices, motor neuron disease, evolutionary graph theory, surgical lighting, postgraduate medical education, stereoelectroencephalography (SEEG), air quality index, vagus nerve stimulation, gut microbiome, trochleoplasty, anticoagulants, transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), surgical coding, proximal junctional kyphosis, anesthetic approaches, neurosurgical risk assessment, spontaneous regression of arteriovenous fistula, statin use, normal pressure hydrocephalus, microbial genomes, and healthy aging.

Research on viral infections includes studying immune responses to RNA viruses and the role of specific proteins in interferon induction. Therapeutic strategies involve quorum sensing inhibitors and anti-biofilm agents against pathogens. The exploration of somatosensory neuron subtypes focuses on their diversity and mechanosensation roles. Health literacy research addresses the readability of online health information. Surgical practices cover topics like pediatric AVMs, trochlear dysplasia classification, and the impact of surgical techniques on outcomes. Motor neuron disease studies emphasize patient experiences and diagnosis delays. Evolutionary graph theory examines selection dynamics, while air quality research analyzes changes during COVID-19. Other studies investigate vagus nerve stimulation, gut microbiome associations with COVID-19, and various surgical and anesthetic practices, highlighting their implications for patient care.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: health information access, community engagement, health behavior, genomic studies, breast cancer risk, financial toxicity in oncology, and BRCA1/2 genetic testing. Health information access focuses on enhancing patient activation in low-income populations regarding chronic conditions like diabetes and depression through localized resources. Community engagement emphasizes participatory health practices and the development of platforms that connect community health resources. Health behavior research investigates tailored interventions to improve health outcomes, including decision aids for lifestyle changes and understanding predictors of health behaviors. Genomic studies explore stakeholder perspectives on polygenic risk scores and barriers to their use, highlighting health literacy issues. Breast cancer risk research examines factors influencing risk assessment, screening practices, and decision-making tools for high-risk women, including chemoprevention uptake. Financial toxicity studies assess the integration of financial screenings in oncology to alleviate economic burdens. Finally, BRCA1/2 genetic testing research addresses cultural influences, mental health correlations, and the need for targeted engagement to improve testing uptake among diverse populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs), drug discovery, arrhythmias, tumor suppressors, PTEN signaling, heart transplantation, proteomics, extracellular matrix (ECM), primary graft dysfunction (PGD), restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM), and engineered cardiac tissue models.

Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) are utilized for drug discovery in arrhythmias, creating in vitro models that improve the understanding of heart rhythm disturbances. Research on tumor suppressors focuses on PTEN, particularly its novel translational variant PTEN-Long, which has potential therapeutic applications in cancer by antagonizing PI3K signaling. Heart transplantation studies emphasize risk stratification and biomarker identification through proteomics, revealing pathways linked to post-transplant survival and primary graft dysfunction (PGD). The extracellular matrix (ECM) is explored in the context of heart failure, highlighting its role in cardiomyocyte function and disease phenotypes. Research on restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM) involves engineered cardiac tissue models to study specific genetic variants, identifying potential therapeutic agents like trequinsin to improve cardiomyocyte relaxation. Overall, this research encompasses innovative approaches to understanding and treating cardiovascular diseases through advanced cellular models and biomarker discovery.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cardiac physiology, calcium channels, adrenergic signaling, protein interactions, Fšrster resonance energy transfer (FRET), ion channel regulation, sodium channels, and therapeutic targets in neurological disorders. 

The research investigates cardiac physiology by focusing on the role of the RGK G protein Rad in the adrenergic regulation of calcium channels, specifically CaV1.2, which are vital for cardiac contractility. It emphasizes the phosphorylation of Rad's domains, linking it to enhanced calcium influx and contraction. The study on protein interactions introduces methodologies for FRET to analyze binding interactions and ion channel dynamics in living cells. The research also delves into ion channel regulation, particularly the ubiquitination of NaV1.5 by NEDD4L, and the development of high-affinity nanobodies for NaV channels. Additionally, it explores the concept of coupled sodium channels, assessing their interactions and implications for neuronal signaling. The research further covers various aspects of calcium channel mechanisms, including voltage-dependent inactivation and alternative splicing, as well as calmodulin's regulatory role in sodium channels, providing insights into potential therapeutic targets for neurological disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein trafficking, SARS-CoV-2 immune evasion, COVID-19 vaccine efficacy, resistance to therapeutic agents, and antiviral development. 

The investigation of HIV-1 envelope glycoprotein trafficking focuses on the mechanisms by which the gp160 Env precursor is processed in the Golgi, leading to the selective incorporation of cleaved forms into virions while uncleaved forms evade immune detection. In the realm of SARS-CoV-2, the researcher examines the immune evasion strategies of various variants, including the assessment of neutralizing antibodies and the impact of specific mutations on treatment efficacy. The efficacy of COVID-19 vaccines against emerging variants is critically analyzed, revealing the limitations of current formulations due to deep immunological imprinting. Additionally, the research highlights the growing resistance of SARS-CoV-2 to therapeutic monoclonal antibodies and small-molecule drugs, emphasizing the need for ongoing surveillance and innovative antiviral strategies to combat future pandemics. Overall, the work contributes significantly to understanding viral dynamics, immune responses, and therapeutic challenges in infectious diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cancer aneuploidy, microplastics in marine life, spatial cognition, HIV Pre-Exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP) adherence, chronic pain and microglial activation, breastfeeding outcomes, coccolithophores biology, human papillomavirus (HPV) and chromosomal instability, immune checkpoint blockade therapy, health disparities in cancer, and sodium intake in chronic kidney disease.

Cancer aneuploidy research focuses on assessing its impact on tumor fitness and identifying cancer driver genes. Microplastics studies investigate their effects on marine life, particularly the physiological stress in fish larvae. Spatial cognition research explores cognitive mechanisms related to spatial compatibility. The PrEP adherence study identifies factors influencing non-adherence among men who have sex with men. Chronic pain research highlights microglial activation in pain-related brain regions. Breastfeeding outcomes research evaluates the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary clinic. Coccolithophores biology examines their role in marine ecosystems, viral interactions, and calcification processes. HPV studies link chromosomal instability to cancer prognosis. Immune checkpoint blockade therapy research investigates long-term responses and immunoresistance in lung cancer. Health disparities research identifies molecular biomarkers in head and neck cancer. Lastly, sodium intake studies in chronic kidney disease explore its relationship with mortality.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pancreatic cancer, therapy resistance, myeloid leukemia, breast cancer, cancer stem cells, microenvironment, cell state plasticity, and hematopoietic stem cells.

In pancreatic cancer, the researcher investigates factors like SMARCD3 and Musashi that contribute to therapy resistance, identifying them as potential therapeutic targets. The role of MARCH E3 ubiquitin ligases in enhancing the efficacy of antitumor therapies is also examined. Myeloid leukemia research focuses on signaling pathways, such as Sdc1-Itg_7 and AMD1, that regulate stem cell maintenance and drug resistance, with implications for targeted therapies. In breast cancer, Ubc13's role in metastasis and the impact of _-catenin on hematopoietic regeneration are explored. The interplay between cancer stem cells and the microenvironment highlights how drug resistance and relapse can stem from aggressive cancer subpopulations. The researcher also studies cell state plasticity in cancer, identifying MSI2+ cells as precursors for various pancreatic cancer subtypes and linking SOX transcription factors to tumor invasiveness. Lastly, the significance of Wnt signaling in hematopoietic stem cell regeneration and its implications for leukemia treatment are emphasized.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: single-molecule field-effect transistors (smFETs), RNA conformational dynamics, kinetic heterogeneity analysis, non-canonical amino acids (ncAAs), translation initiation mechanisms, ribosomal dynamics, Bayesian inference in single-molecule experiments, and cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM).

Single-molecule field-effect transistors (smFETs) are utilized to investigate the conformational free-energy landscape of RNA stem-loops, revealing complex (un)folding behavior. RNA conformational dynamics focus on understanding the folding and unfolding processes of RNA structures over milliseconds. Kinetic heterogeneity analysis, through the hFRET algorithm, characterizes variations in transition rates in single-molecule data, enhancing insights into ribosomal pre-translocation dynamics. Research on non-canonical amino acids (ncAAs) emphasizes their incorporation into peptides and their effects on translation processes. Translation initiation mechanisms explore factors like NusG and eIF4GI, which regulate gene expression and cap-independent translation during stress. Ribosomal dynamics studies reveal the structural and functional changes in ribosomes during translation initiation and elongation, with a focus on the roles of initiation factors. Bayesian inference techniques are applied to improve the analysis of single-molecule data, while cryo-EM advancements provide insights into ribosome conformational changes during translation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: mitochondrial diseases, mitochondrial replacement techniques, mitochondrial DNA editing, neurodegenerative diseases, Alzheimer's disease, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, mitochondria-associated ER membranes (MAM), oxidative phosphorylation (OxPhos) deficiencies, mitochondrial genetics, and therapeutic strategies.

Mitochondrial diseases are a central theme, with a focus on mitochondrial replacement techniques aimed at preventing the transmission of disorders. The researcher explores mitochondrial DNA editing as a more precise alternative to replacement methods. In neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's and Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, the role of MAM is emphasized, linking altered function to disease pathogenesis. The MAM hypothesis suggests a connection between mitochondrial dysfunction and cholesterol metabolism in Alzheimer's, while mutations in MFN2 and SCO2 are associated with specific forms of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. The researcher also investigates the implications of oxidative phosphorylation deficiencies and their contribution to disease onset. Additionally, the potential of low-dose rapamycin as a therapeutic avenue and the significance of mtDNA heteroplasmy in stem cell variability are highlighted, underscoring the complexity of mitochondrial genetics and the need for innovative therapeutic strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cognitive impairments, dementia, essential tremor, neuropsychological assessments, racial and ethnic disparities in dementia diagnosis, Alzheimer's disease, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), financial decision-making, digital technology in cognitive assessment, and genetic factors in cognitive longevity.

Cognitive impairments are a primary focus, particularly in dementia and essential tremor cohorts, with studies highlighting conversion rates to mild cognitive impairment and the importance of subjective cognitive decline as an early marker. Research on neuropsychological assessments emphasizes task strategies over summary scores, with digital platforms enhancing data collection. The investigation of racial and ethnic disparities reveals systemic issues in dementia misidentification within Medicare claims. Alzheimer's disease research identifies genetic links, cognitive predictors, and the impact of impaired self-awareness on clinical outcomes. In ALS, a prodromal phase is explored, while studies on financial decision-making correlate cognitive function with white matter integrity. Digital technology is examined for its role in assessing cognitive function, and genetic factors are linked to exceptional memory performance in long-lived families, underscoring the complex interplay of cognitive and functional decline across aging populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: sensorimotor striatum, motor skill learning, thalamocortical loops, neural dynamics, motor control, recurrent networks, artificial intelligence (AI), and NeuroAI.

The sensorimotor striatum research investigates how it differentiates between automatic and visually guided motor sequences, revealing that lesions affect automatic behaviors more than visually guided ones, indicating the basal ganglia's role in automatic motor skills. In motor skill learning, the focus is on the transition from cortical to subcortical control, emphasizing the thalamus's role in habit formation and the execution of learned behaviors. Thalamocortical loops research highlights the thalamus's influence on cortical dynamics during learning, with findings supporting the importance of corticothalamic connectivity. Neural dynamics and motor control studies propose models for thalamic control over cortical interactions to facilitate flexible motor sequencing. The recurrent networks research introduces a novel training method, full-FORCE, enhancing network performance with temporally complex tasks. Lastly, the AI and NeuroAI directions advocate for AI development through embodied Turing tests, emphasizing the importance of sensorimotor interactions over traditional human-centric capabilities, aiming to advance AI by leveraging insights from neuroscience.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: rheumatoid arthritis (RA), cardiovascular disease (CVD), psoriatic arthritis (PsA), clinical trials, inflammation, biomarkers, immunomodulators, and interstitial lung disease (ILD). 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) research focuses on the cardiovascular implications, including the association between RA and heart failure risks, particularly through left ventricular remodeling and the role of interleukin-6 (IL-6). The impact of RA treatments, such as tocilizumab, on cardiac function and lipid changes is also explored. In psoriatic arthritis (PsA), genetic factors and HLA alleles are investigated for their influence on disease phenotypes. Clinical trials research addresses coordination challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic, emphasizing the need for efficient communication to avoid redundancy in studies. Inflammation's role in cardiovascular health is highlighted, with a focus on biomarkers like galectin-3 and the potential of immunomodulators to mitigate cardiovascular events. Additionally, the researcher examines the relationship between adipokines and lung function in ILD, as well as the psychosocial factors affecting cardiovascular health in RA patients.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: blood pressure measurement, hypertension management, cardiovascular disease (CVD), antihypertensive medication adherence, psychosocial factors in cardiovascular health, ambulatory blood pressure monitoring, and racial disparities in hypertension. Blood pressure measurement studies focus on the accuracy of various devices and methods, including office, home, and cuffless monitoring, emphasizing their implications for hypertension management. Hypertension management research addresses gaps in control and proposes strategies like team-based care and lifestyle changes. CVD research highlights the impact of hypertension as a risk factor and explores the consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on prevention and management. Antihypertensive medication adherence studies reveal low adherence rates across demographics, including children and specific racial groups. Psychosocial factors research examines the effects of negative emotions on cardiovascular health. Ambulatory blood pressure monitoring studies assess its underutilization and efficacy in diagnosing conditions like white coat hypertension. Finally, research on racial disparities investigates the prevalence of hypertension and its association with cardiovascular events, particularly in African American populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: contrast perception, straddle effect, first-order and second-order visual patterns, contrast-comparison processes, contrast-normalization processes, psychophysical modeling. 

Contrast perception is a primary focus, examining how individuals perceive differences in visual contrast. The straddle effect is a specific phenomenon investigated, where adaptation to a uniform contrast impairs the ability to perceive test contrasts that straddle the adapt contrast. This research challenges previous assumptions by demonstrating that the straddle effect occurs in both first-order and second-order visual patterns, with a slight performance drop in first-order tasks attributed to memory load. The dynamics of contrast-comparison and contrast-normalization processes are explored through varying test-pattern durations, revealing that performance remains poor for test patterns above and below the adaptation contrast. A simple model that incorporates these processes provides a framework for understanding the psychophysical findings, shedding light on how contrast processing may rely on the unsigned difference between current and recent average contrasts rather than a direct relationship with physical contrast.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: retinal ganglion cell (RGC) neurogenesis, Wnt signaling, developmental biology, immunology, neuronal connectivity, axon guidance, vaccine development, alcohol's effects on tuberculosis, Drosophila neuropil development, thalamocortical and corticocortical synapses, and tissue clearing methods.

RGC neurogenesis studies focus on the impact of Cyclin D2 and the ciliary margin zone (CMZ) in albinism, revealing disrupted neurogenesis and depth perception issues. Wnt signaling from the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) is linked to reduced ipsilateral RGCs. In developmental biology, the roles of Semaphorin-6D and Plexin-A1 in axon positioning are investigated, along with the necessity of Autophagy linked FYVE protein (Alfy) for neuronal connectivity. Immunology research includes a neonatal immune priming strategy for tuberculosis vaccines and DNA-launched alphavirus replicons. The effects of chronic alcohol consumption on tuberculosis mortality highlight immune response alterations. Drosophila studies reveal lineage sharing between motor neurons and glia for neuropil development. Lastly, comparisons of thalamocortical and corticocortical synapses explore synaptic strength, and the ClearT method enhances tissue visualization while preserving morphology.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: stem cell signaling, neuronal function, calcium signaling, cardiac development, and developmental biology. 

Stem cell signaling investigates the Slit-Robo and JAK-STAT pathways in Drosophila testis stem cell niches, emphasizing how these pathways influence stem cell competition and functionality through modulation of cell adhesion and niche occupancy. Neuronal function focuses on the discovery of a mammalian nervous-system-specific plasma membrane proteasome complex that degrades intracellular proteins into extracellular peptides, impacting neuronal signaling and calcium signaling. Calcium signaling is explored in the context of ventricular hypertrophy during zebrafish development, revealing its independence from contraction and its critical role in cardiomyocyte hypertrophy. Cardiac development research emphasizes the role of L-type CaV1.2 channels in mandibular development, particularly in Timothy Syndrome, demonstrating their influence on cellular hypertrophy and hyperplasia. Lastly, developmental biology research on the 20S neuronal membrane proteasome in Xenopus laevis tadpoles highlights its role in regulating neuronal circuit activity and learning-induced behavioral plasticity through the degradation of newly synthesized proteins.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), lung and airway cell differentiation, regenerative medicine, disease modeling, drug screening, influenza and interferon responses, genetic deficiencies in immunity, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), hematopoiesis, leukemia, stem cell biology, interstitial lung disease, calcium regulation in stem cells, mitochondrial regulation, and aging in the hematopoietic system.

The researcher focuses on hPSCs to generate lung and airway cells for applications in regenerative medicine and disease modeling. They have developed protocols for differentiating hPSCs into various lung cell types and explored the role of signaling pathways like NOTCH in cell fate specification. Their work on influenza highlights genetic deficiencies in interferon responses that lead to severe complications, emphasizing the importance of type I and III IFN immunity. In IPF research, they investigate the effects of specific mutations on fibrotic changes and potential therapeutic targets. Their studies on hematopoiesis reveal the roles of PRDM16 isoforms in stem cell maintenance and inflammation. Additionally, they examine the context-dependent role of FLT3 in leukemia initiation. The research also delves into stem cell maintenance mechanisms, including calcium regulation and mitochondrial dynamics, and explores aging effects on hematopoietic stem cells.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neural mechanisms, social memory, spatial working memory, neural coding, hippocampal function, prefrontal cortex, neural selectivity, radiation therapy, surgical techniques, decision-making, and neuromorphic engineering. 

The research investigates neural mechanisms related to social and spatial working memory, revealing that social memory involves distinct encoding processes for familiar and novel individuals, with higher-dimensional representations enhancing memory capacity. The hippocampal CA2 region is shown to play a critical role in social interactions, while direct connections between the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex are essential for encoding spatial cues. In terms of neural coding, studies explore mixed selectivity and the dynamics of place cells, emphasizing their role in memory representation and cognitive tasks. Additionally, the research addresses the effects of radiation on surgical reconstruction techniques, such as DIEP flap procedures, and evaluates the timing of interventions in relation to complications. Decision-making processes are examined through the lens of neural network models, highlighting adaptive strategies in behavior. Lastly, advancements in neuromorphic engineering reveal energy-efficient classification methods, contributing to the understanding of neural circuits and their applications in artificial intelligence.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: memory processing, neural oscillations, end-of-life care, orthopedic implants, cardiovascular health, interprofessional education, and computational modeling. 

Memory processing research focuses on how theta and alpha waves influence human memory encoding and recall, highlighting their role in neural connectivity. Neural oscillations are examined through the interaction of theta and gamma waves, particularly in the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe, which support episodic memory. In the area of end-of-life care, insights into Jewish beliefs provide valuable perspectives for clinicians in palliative settings. Orthopedic implant research investigates the degradation of cobalt-chromium-molybdenum alloys and their inflammatory responses, while also addressing complications from metal-on-metal hip replacements and the importance of risk stratification. Cardiovascular health studies reveal disparities in statin use and medication adherence in hypertension management. Interprofessional education initiatives aim to enhance collaboration among health professionals. Lastly, computational modeling is utilized to estimate mechanics in total hip arthroplasty and evaluate the implications of taper corrosion on implant failure, emphasizing the need for improved diagnostic tools in orthopedic surgery.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurodegenerative diseases, neuroinflammation, gliogenesis, oligodendrocyte biology, stroke recovery, astrocyte function, glioblastoma, and SARS-CoV-2 neuropathology.

Neurodegenerative diseases are a primary focus, with studies on frontotemporal dementia and Huntington's disease highlighting the roles of osteopontin and galectin-3 in neuroinflammation and cell loss. Neuroinflammation is explored through the impact of galectin-3 on postnatal subventricular zone gliogenesis, affecting astrocyte and oligodendrocyte proliferation. Oligodendrocyte biology is examined, revealing maturation deficits that can be rescued by thiamine-biotin supplementation. Stroke recovery research indicates that galectin-3 deletion affects angiogenesis but not neurogenesis or microglial responses. Astrocyte function is investigated, particularly the role of CD44 in health and disease, and variable astrocyte states in Huntington's disease are characterized through single-nucleus RNA sequencing. Glioblastoma studies reveal distinct tissue states and their correlation with prognosis. Lastly, SARS-CoV-2 neuropathology is assessed, highlighting unique findings related to microglial activation and neuronophagia in infected patients.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: lung health, cellular responses, retinoid biology, regulatory T cells, macrophage efferocytosis, human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), mitochondrial biology, inflammation, influenza A virus (IAV) infection, pulmonary surfactant therapy, and bacterial interactions in lung injury.

Lung health is a primary focus, investigating mechanisms of injury and repair, including the role of retinoids in mitigating acute lung injury. The research on cellular responses highlights the function of regulatory T cells in enhancing macrophage efferocytosis during inflammation resolution. Human pluripotent stem cells are explored for generating lung epithelial cells, crucial for regenerative medicine. Mitochondrial biology studies emphasize the role of mitochondrial uncoupling protein 2 and calcium uniporter in lung pathology. Inflammation research includes the effects of IAV on alveolar epithelial cells and macrophage interactions. Additionally, pulmonary surfactant therapy has been shown to improve outcomes in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. The research also delves into bacterial interactions during influenza-staphylococcal coinfection, revealing insights into lung injury mechanisms and potential therapeutic strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: epilepsy, neurosurgery, surgical interventions, clinical practices, healthcare quality improvement, neuro-oncology, and neuroanatomy. 

Epilepsy research focuses on drug-resistant epilepsy (DRE), emphasizing the need for comprehensive neurodiagnostic evaluations and identifying patient pathways for specialized care. Neurosurgery studies include various surgical techniques and outcomes, such as the efficacy of magnetic resonance-guided laser interstitial thermal therapy and the safety of stereoelectroencephalography in pediatric patients. Surgical interventions also explore minimally invasive techniques, such as endoscopic endonasal approaches for meningiomas and the use of acellular dermal matrix for skull base repair. Clinical practices examine the importance of understanding neurosurgery billing, readmission patterns, and infection risks in surgical settings. Healthcare quality improvement initiatives aim to enhance patient outcomes through better care measurement and adherence to clinical practice guidelines. Neuro-oncology research addresses venous thromboembolism prophylaxis and long-term outcomes in pediatric spinal fusion patients. Lastly, neuroanatomy studies investigate the neuroanatomical factors influencing treatment responses in obsessive-compulsive disorder and the role of substantia nigra neurons in novelty detection.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: hippocampal function, episodic memory, neurodevelopment, emotional behavior, neurogenesis, nonverbal learning disabilities (NVLD), tissue clearing methods, and aging-related memory loss. 

Hippocampal function and episodic memory are explored through the capacity of infants to form memories despite immature circuitry. Neurodevelopment research focuses on how norepinephrine and serotonin signaling during sensitive periods affect anxiety and depression-like behaviors. Neurogenesis is investigated for its role in maintaining cholinergic inputs and working memory, particularly in aging, while early life stress is shown to impair hippocampal development and adult neurogenesis. The study of NVLD reveals structural and functional hippocampal changes that affect cognitive abilities and social functioning. Tissue clearing methods, specifically Fast 3D Clear, are developed for imaging brain tissues, enhancing the study of neurodevelopmental disorders. Lastly, the role of RbAp48 in age-related memory loss is examined, highlighting its regulation of critical signaling pathways in the hippocampus that may mitigate cognitive decline.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: novel synthetic opioids (NSOs), mitragynine alkaloids, G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs), calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR), serotonin transporters (SERT), dopamine receptors, and allosteric mechanisms in transporters.

Research on novel synthetic opioids focuses on their interactions with _-opioid receptors, revealing high intrinsic efficacy and overdose risks associated with fentanyl and nitazene analogs. Mitragynine alkaloids are explored for their respiratory depressant effects and potential for safer opioid medications, with novel analogs showing low efficacy while providing pain relief. The GPCR research investigates various receptor signaling mechanisms, including arrestin interactions, and the role of latrophilin-2 in axon targeting. The calcium-sensing receptor studies reveal promiscuous G-protein coupling and structural insights into receptor activation. The development of SERTlight enhances imaging of serotonergic neurons, while dopamine receptor studies highlight their roles in locomotion and weight loss. Additionally, allosteric mechanisms in SLC6 transporters are examined for their substrate specificity and potential as drug targets, emphasizing the importance of understanding these mechanisms for therapeutic advancements.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: ischemic acute kidney injury (AKI), inflammation, Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9), Paneth cells, norepinephrine, cathepsins, P2X4 purinergic receptor, renal proximal tubular NF-_B essential modulator (NEMO), short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), and therapeutic targets for organ injury.

The researcher investigates ischemic AKI, focusing on mechanisms that exacerbate or protect against this condition. Key findings include the role of inflammation and TLR9 in worsening AKI, with TLR9 deficiency leading to increased organ injury and inflammation. Paneth cells are identified as a source of norepinephrine, which exacerbates renal injury. Cathepsins are implicated in multi-organ ischemia-reperfusion injury, acting as mediators of inflammation and apoptosis. The P2X4 receptor is highlighted for its detrimental effects on renal inflammation, while NEMO is crucial for managing inflammation in AKI. The research also explores the protective roles of SCFAs and renalase against AKI. Overall, the findings suggest potential therapeutic targets, including selective TLR9 antagonists and cathepsin inhibitors, for preventing and treating ischemic organ injuries.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: microglia, metabolism, obesity, mood disorders, osteoblast function, glucose metabolism, mitochondrial dynamics, neurobiology, and women's contributions in science. 

Microglia are studied for their dual role as immune cells and metabolic sensors, influencing energy homeostasis. Research on metabolism includes the interplay between obesity and mood disorders, particularly through melanocortin signaling and the effects of bile acids on satiety. The role of microglia in synaptic remodeling and anxiety is also explored. Osteoblast function is examined in relation to nutrient availability and mitochondrial dynamics, shedding light on energy requirements for bone synthesis. In glucose metabolism, various mechanisms are investigated, such as the effects of TET3 and UCP2 on insulin sensitivity and feeding behavior. Mitochondrial dynamics in hypothalamic neurons are crucial for metabolic regulation, while the research also highlights the importance of women's contributions to metabolism through the "Women in Metabolism" series, celebrating female scientists' achievements in this field.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: liver transplantation, small-for-size syndrome (SFSS), laparoscopic donor hepatectomy, artificial intelligence in healthcare, organ procurement education, hepatocellular carcinoma, machine preservation, split liver transplantation, noninvasive biomarkers, and infectious disease management in transplant recipients. 

Liver transplantation is a primary focus, with particular attention to managing SFSS through pharmacological therapy and surgical options. The researcher explores laparoscopic donor hepatectomy as a minimally invasive technique, advocating for its adoption due to safety and efficacy. Artificial intelligence is employed to predict hepatocellular cancer recurrence post-transplant, enhancing decision-making in transplant candidacy. The significance of organ procurement education is highlighted, revealing gaps in formal training for medical students. The research also investigates machine preservation and split liver transplantation, aiming to optimize donor organ usage. Noninvasive biomarkers are being developed to improve transplant outcomes, while the impact of COVID-19 on transplant recipients and the management of infections like carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae are critically examined.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cancer genomics, prognostic modeling, single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), computational biology, cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), and epigenetics. 

Cancer genomics is a significant focus, with studies identifying pan-cancer driver copy number alterations and co-expression signatures associated with oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes. Prognostic modeling is advanced through the development of models using attractor metagenes for breast cancer survival, integrating features like chromosomal instability and immune recruitment. Single-cell RNA sequencing research includes the CASCC method for enhanced clustering and the 2DImpute method for correcting false zeros in scRNA-seq data. Computational biology is applied to deconvolve tumor heterogeneity and infer subclonal structures, revealing type-specific mutations. The transition of adipose-derived stromal cells to CAFs is investigated, highlighting their role in cancer progression and therapy resistance. Lastly, the research explores epigenetic mechanisms in neuropsychiatric disorders, enhancing understanding of stress-related biological processes. Together, these studies contribute to improved cancer biology insights and prognostic capabilities.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: health outcomes, cervical spondylotic myelopathy, machine learning, spine surgery, minimally invasive techniques, dietary impacts on cancer risk, deep brain stimulation, healthcare disparities, endoscopic procedures, biopsy techniques, and antibiotic use in cancer. 

Health outcomes research focuses on predictors and satisfaction levels in cervical spondylotic myelopathy patients, assessing factors like upper versus lower extremity function and the impact of comorbidities such as depression and anxiety. Machine learning applications include algorithms for predicting recovery outcomes and hospital stays in spine surgery patients. In spine surgery, studies evaluate the efficacy of topical tranexamic acid, the adequacy of risk adjustment models, and complications related to image guidance. Minimally invasive techniques are compared to traditional methods, showing improved patient outcomes. Dietary research explores links between inflammation and cancer risk, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma, while the role of aspirin in cancer prevention is investigated. Deep brain stimulation trends reveal disparities in access for African Americans. Endoscopic procedures and biopsy techniques are analyzed for their safety and effectiveness in treating various conditions, including idiopathic normal-pressure hydrocephalus and neuromuscular disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: biomarkers, pyelonephritis, extrinsic skin aging, oligodendroglial macroautophagy, neurodegenerative diseases, macrophage efferocytosis, autophagy, COVID-19, atopic dermatitis, stem cell research, and pathogenicity of probiotics.

The researcher investigates urine neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL) as a biomarker for adult pyelonephritis, aiming to differentiate pyelonephritis from non-pyelonephritis cases. They also explore extrinsic skin aging across different ethnicities, highlighting variations in aging patterns among German, Chinese, and Japanese women. In neurobiology, the role of oligodendroglial macroautophagy is examined for its importance in myelin sheath turnover and neurodegeneration prevention. The research on macrophage efferocytosis identifies WDFY3 as a key regulator in apoptotic cell clearance, while autophagy's role in neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington's and Parkinson's, is emphasized. Additionally, the impact of high D-glucose levels on ACE2 expression in airway epithelial cells is studied in relation to COVID-19 risk. The researcher also investigates thromboxane A2's role in itch responses in atopic dermatitis and assesses neuronal development in stem cell research. Lastly, they document a case of necrotizing fasciitis linked to Bifidobacterium breve, highlighting its potential pathogenicity.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: healthcare disparities, electronic health records (EHR), machine learning, patient engagement, emergency department (ED) care, biomedical informatics, citizen science, online health communities, predictive modeling, and patient safety.

Healthcare disparities research focuses on understanding and addressing inequities in health outcomes, particularly influenced by social determinants of health. Electronic health records (EHR) studies emphasize improving data quality and representation in health research, exploring issues like phenotype definitions and the role of structured data in detecting social and behavioral determinants of health. Machine learning applications include developing clinical decision support systems, predicting chronic disease risks, and automating EHR summarization. Patient engagement research examines self-tracking data, particularly in conditions like endometriosis, to enhance involvement in care. Emergency department care studies investigate the impact of boarding duration on mental health outcomes, highlighting risks like delirium. Biomedical informatics encompasses machine learning for analyzing clinical texts and identifying biases in EHR data. Citizen science and online health communities research focuses on health disparities, user engagement, and content analysis. Predictive modeling efforts aim to improve resource allocation in healthcare, while patient safety studies address issues like wrong-patient imaging orders and the development of tools like HARVEST for patient summarization.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cell-cycle regulation, CDK4/6, Rb protein, receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) activation, ERK signaling, drug resistance in melanoma, angiogenesis, immunotherapy, and single-cell imaging techniques. 

Cell-cycle regulation is a primary focus, particularly the mechanisms involving CDK4/6 and Rb protein, highlighting non-canonical pathways for Rb inactivation and the role of CDK2 in cell-cycle commitment. The research on RTK activation kinetics explores how these dynamics contribute to ERK reactivation and the development of drug-resistant melanoma cells. Angiogenesis, specifically the role of ANGPT2 in T-cell exclusion from tumors, is investigated to enhance immunotherapy efficacy in melanoma and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. The researcher employs single-cell imaging techniques to overcome challenges in understanding cell-cycle progression and heterogeneity, facilitating insights into molecular mechanisms. Additionally, the work on CDK4/6 inhibitors in breast cancer emphasizes the development of resistance through E2F activation and potential therapeutic strategies to counteract this resistance.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: retinal diseases, Stargardt disease, ABCA4-associated conditions, genetic mutations, multimodal imaging, genotype-phenotype correlations, choroidal changes, and ABC transporter superfamily. 

Retinal diseases are a primary focus, particularly Stargardt disease and ABCA4-related conditions, where studies utilize multimodal imaging to track disease progression and identify genetic mutations. The researcher investigates specific genetic mutations, such as those in the ABCA4 gene, and their implications for disease severity and phenotypic variability. Genotype-phenotype correlations are developed to predict long-term outcomes for patients with ABCA4 mutations. Choroidal changes are also examined, particularly in relation to conditions like preeclampsia and their impact on retinal health. The ABC transporter superfamily is explored for its role in substrate efflux and its connections to various human disorders, including retinal degeneration. Overall, the research emphasizes the intricate genetic landscape of retinal disorders and the potential for targeted genetic analysis and therapies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurological disorders, synaptic dynamics, neurotransmitter systems, immune responses in neurodegenerative diseases, sensory signaling, dopamine dynamics, and neuroinflammation. 

In neurological disorders, the researcher investigates mechanisms such as auxilin mutations in Parkinson's disease, Tsc1 knockout in tuberous sclerosis complex, and the role of chaperone-mediated autophagy in Alzheimer's disease. Synaptic dynamics are explored through the development of fluorescent probes like SERTlight for serotonin and polymer platforms for voltage-sensitive dyes, enhancing imaging in dopaminergic neurons. The neurotransmitter systems focus on _-synuclein's dual role in dopamine release and alterations in cholinergic interneurons linked to dyskinesia. Immune responses in neurodegenerative diseases examine T cell responses and MHC-I expression in microglia and neurons, highlighting their roles in Parkinson's and ALS. Sensory signaling research includes Merkel cells activating sensory pathways. Dopamine dynamics are studied through various imaging techniques and their influence on learning and neurodegeneration, particularly in Parkinson's disease, while neuroinflammation is investigated for its impact on neuronal health and disease progression.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: biomechanics, musculoskeletal injuries, neuroimmunology, Alzheimer's disease (AD), microglia, dance medicine, and reporting guidelines in biomechanics. 

Biomechanics research focuses on the measurement and analysis of physical performance and injury risk, utilizing technologies like inertial measurement units and three-dimensional motion capture. Studies on musculoskeletal injuries emphasize the assessment of loading patterns in athletes, such as gymnasts and dancers, and the prevalence of low back pain in dancers. Neuroimmunology explores the role of immune cells, particularly microglia, in neurodegenerative diseases like AD, highlighting their transcriptomic signatures and involvement in neurogenesis and cognitive decline. Research on AD further examines genetic factors, immune responses, and the effects of aging on microglial function. Dance medicine investigates injury risk factors related to growth and alignment in ballet dancers. Lastly, the establishment of comprehensive reporting guidelines aims to standardize research methodologies in biomechanics and footwear studies, enhancing the quality and reproducibility of findings in these interdisciplinary fields.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cognitive decline, dementia risk, psychosocial factors, education and cognitive reserve, HIV and cognitive function, substance use and medication adherence, mild cognitive impairment (MCI), cardiovascular health, cultural neuropsychology, and cognitive assessment.

Cognitive decline is a central theme, with studies examining factors like C-reactive protein levels and psychological predictors affecting memory across diverse populations. Dementia risk is explored, particularly among non-Hispanic Black older adults, focusing on psychosocial stressors and educational disparities. The relationship between education and the APOE _4 allele's impact on memory performance is also investigated. Research on HIV+ adults highlights how HIV infection and substance use contribute to cognitive deficits and medication adherence challenges, with nonsomatic depressive symptoms emerging as significant predictors. The prevalence of MCI and its subtypes in aging Mexican populations is examined, linking midlife cardiovascular risk factors to late-life cognitive decline. Lastly, a cultural neuropsychological framework is proposed to harmonize cognitive assessments across diverse populations, ensuring cultural sensitivity and enhancing data reliability.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: multiple myeloma (MM), AL amyloidosis, immunology, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), imaging techniques, therapeutic targets, and drug efficacy. 

In the field of multiple myeloma, the researcher investigates the role of PD-1H in osteoclast activation, imaging advancements for early bone disease detection, and the efficacy of various drug combinations, including selinexor and venetoclax. Research on AL amyloidosis focuses on daratumumab-based therapies, light chain isotype differences, and screening tools for early diagnosis. The immunology aspect includes studies on the absence of Stat1 in donor T cells and its effects on Treg expansion and GVHD, as well as the role of IFN-_R/STAT1 signaling in antigen presentation and immune responses. Imaging techniques, particularly WB DW-MRI and FDG PET/CT, are explored for their impact on treatment decisions. Additionally, the researcher examines therapeutic targets like GCK in RAS-mutated MM and the use of bisphosphonates in elderly patients. Overall, the research emphasizes innovative strategies for diagnosing and treating hematologic malignancies and associated conditions.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: myelofibrosis, hematopoietic stem cell differentiation, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), protein-RNA interactions, alternative splicing, splicing-regulatory elements (SREs), breast cancer, and drug delivery systems.

In myelofibrosis, the researcher identifies Sox10+ glial cells as therapeutic targets and explores the origin of myofibroblasts from LepR+ mesenchymal cells. For hematopoietic stem cell differentiation, the role of Mettl3-dependent m6A mRNA methylation is examined, revealing its impact on HSC accumulation and differentiation. In autism spectrum disorder, the research reconstructs autism biology through genetic mutation profiles, proposing a gene + pathway dual-hit model and identifying haploinsufficient autism-susceptibility genes.

The studies on protein-RNA interactions introduce tools like PxR3D-map and mCross for predicting crosslinking sites and modeling RNA-binding protein specificity. Alternative splicing research highlights its implications in neuronal function, with findings on the MAPT gene and the role of SLM2 in synapse specification. The development of SpliceRUSH enables high-throughput screening of SREs, while breast cancer research focuses on predicting pathological complete response and developing biodegradable mesoporous silica nanoparticles for enhanced therapy.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: obesity, insulin resistance, metabolic dysfunction, hepatic pathways, cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, reproductive health, thrombosis, immune response, cholesterol metabolism, and inflammation resolution.

Obesity research focuses on molecular mechanisms contributing to insulin resistance and metabolic dysfunction, including the role of adipocyte CAMK2 and hepatocyte-secreted DPP4. Studies reveal that targeting these pathways can improve glucose homeostasis and insulin sensitivity. The investigation of hepatic PAI-1/tPA pathways highlights their role in impaired fibrinolysis and potential therapeutic targets for thrombosis. In cardiovascular disease and type 2 diabetes, the interplay of Rap1 and PCSK9 is explored, suggesting joint therapeutic targets. Research on reproductive health examines the effects of cetrorelix dosing on progesterone levels in patients with poor ovarian response, indicating complications in IVF outcomes. The immune response in visceral adipose tissue is assessed, revealing limited contributions to obesity-related metabolic dysfunction. Additionally, cholesterol metabolism is influenced by hepatic Rap1a and glucagon signaling, while inflammation resolution mechanisms involving resolvin D1 offer insights for new therapeutic strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: prostate cancer, interleukin-8 (IL-8) signaling, E-cadherin and Desmoglein 2 (DSG2), advanced skin models, alopecia areata (AA), single-cell RNA sequencing, JAK inhibitors, genetic studies, and stem cell therapies.

Prostate cancer research focuses on the role of IL-8 in promoting tumor-supportive immune cell infiltration and potential therapeutic strategies targeting the IL-8/CXCR2 axis. Investigations into E-cadherin and DSG2 reveal their correlation with cancer aggressiveness and biochemical recurrence, with the PI3K/AKT pathway influencing E-cadherin expression. Advanced skin models for drug testing include 3D constructs with T cells and iPSC-derived cells, enhancing understanding of skin diseases and drug efficacy. In alopecia areata, research utilizes single-cell RNA sequencing to identify CD8+ T cell subsets driving the disease, while JAK inhibitors show promise in treatment. Genetic studies have linked rare variants to AA risk and explored comorbidities, paving the way for precision medicine. Overall, the integration of immunological, genetic, and advanced modeling approaches aims to improve understanding and treatment of these conditions.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: gut-brain axis, taste perception, neural mechanisms, fat preference, sugar preference, high salt aversion, inflammatory responses, taste memory, thermosensory system, thirst regulation, and asthma.

The gut-brain axis is investigated for its role in mediating sugar preference, revealing that sugar preference can occur without sweet taste receptors, with specific vagal neurons activated by sugar.
