This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: retroviral interactions, host cellular mechanisms, transmissible cancers, evolutionary dynamics, histone modifications, DNA replication, stem cell biology, and ubiquitin ligase complexes. 

In retroviral interactions, studies focus on chromatin immunoprecipitation methods to analyze unintegrated retroviral DNAs and the influence of histone modifications on transcriptional silencing. Host cellular mechanisms are explored through the roles of proteins like ZAP and CHAF1A/B in HIV-1 restriction and silencing. The study of transmissible cancers examines their evolutionary dynamics in marine bivalves, revealing high mutation rates and cross-species transmission of cancer lineages. Histone modifications are investigated through the asymmetric distribution of H3K9me3 during DNA replication, highlighting the role of the HUSH complex. Stem cell biology research identifies Prrx1-expressing cells as essential for tissue homeostasis, regulated by Wnt signaling. Lastly, the characterization of the CUL4-DDB1 ubiquitin ligase complex reveals its critical role in stem cell differentiation and maintenance, with implications for hematopoiesis and post-translational regulation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Alzheimer's disease (AD), cognitive reserve, neuroimaging, neurophysiological markers, lifestyle factors, cognitive performance, dementia, tau deposition, personality traits, cognitive polygenic index, neuropsychiatric symptoms, resilience science, healthcare utilization, and physical activity.

Alzheimer's disease research focuses on understanding its progression, identifying key risk factors, and developing predictive algorithms for patient outcomes. Cognitive reserve studies investigate how factors like education and personality traits influence cognitive performance and resilience against cognitive decline. Neuroimaging and neurophysiological markers are utilized to explore relationships between brain structure and cognitive function, particularly in aging populations. Lifestyle factors, including diet and physical activity, are examined for their impact on cognitive health. Tau deposition research assesses its correlation with cognitive decline, while cognitive polygenic index studies explore genetic influences on cognition. Neuropsychiatric symptoms are linked to poorer outcomes in dementia, and resilience science aims to establish frameworks for studying aging. Finally, healthcare utilization research highlights the financial burdens of dementia care, emphasizing the need for integrated approaches to address cognitive decline and its consequences.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pediatric cardiac surgery, congenital heart disease, echocardiography, tissue engineering, cardiac valve procedures, surgical techniques, and postoperative care. Pediatric cardiac surgery focuses on surgical interventions for congenital heart defects, including the evaluation of complications such as left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) post-interrupted aortic arch repair. In congenital heart disease, the researcher investigates mortality rates associated with pulmonary vein stenosis and the impact of aortic regurgitation on autograft durability in the Ross procedure. Echocardiography is utilized to identify predictors for reintervention. Tissue engineering explores innovations such as biostable polymeric trileaflet valved conduits and tissue-engineered heart valves (TEHVs) to improve outcomes in pediatric patients. Cardiac valve procedures examine hydrodynamic properties and mechanical considerations for valve development. Surgical techniques include minimally invasive approaches and hybrid interventions, while postoperative care emphasizes the complexities of managing patients, such as those with Ebstein anomaly following the Starnes procedure, and the evaluation of valved versus nonvalved Sano conduits in the Norwood operation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: liver transplantation, living liver donors, cardiovascular assessment, visceral adiposity, statin use, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), simultaneous liver-kidney transplantation (SLKT), gastrointestinal pathogen testing, patient loneliness, frailty, healthcare utilization, chronic kidney disease, COVID-19 impact, hepatitis C virus (HCV) treatment, and antimicrobial stewardship.

Liver transplantation research focuses on improving outcomes and addressing challenges for candidates, including evaluating living liver donors and assessing cardiovascular health in patients with comorbidities. The impact of visceral adiposity on cirrhosis severity and the protective role of statins in chronic liver disease are explored. Studies on NAFLD-related HCC outcomes reveal comparable survival rates to non-NAFLD patients. Research on SLKT highlights recipient age and chronic kidney disease prevalence, while gastrointestinal pathogen testing is examined for its relevance in transplant recipients. The researcher also investigates the implications of loneliness and frailty on post-transplant healthcare needs. Chronic kidney disease's association with transplant outcomes and the effects of COVID-19 on liver transplant practices are addressed. The HCV-TARGET study emphasizes early treatment benefits in HCV-positive transplant scenarios, while the need for antimicrobial stewardship guidelines is identified to mitigate infection risks in transplant recipients.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: early life adversity (ELA), anxiety disorders, fear learning, mood disorders, olfactory function, neuroprotection, and sex differences in neurobiology. 

Early life adversity (ELA) is a significant focus, examining its impact on anxiety and coping strategies, particularly highlighting sex-specific responses in mice. The research indicates that ELA alters stress physiology and social behavior, with females showing heightened anxiety-like behaviors. In the context of fear learning, the role of BDNF Val66Met SNP is explored, revealing its effects on contextual fear expression and hippocampal function. Mood disorders are investigated through the lens of olfactory sensory function, where disruptions in olfactory perception are linked to depressive states. Neuroprotection is addressed through studies on inter-alpha inhibitor proteins (IAIPs) and their efficacy against hypoxic-ischemic brain injury, demonstrating sex-dependent outcomes. Finally, the research emphasizes the importance of considering sex differences in neurobiology, particularly in understanding the long-term consequences of ELA on mental health and the development of neuropsychiatric disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: central sensitization, endometriosis, tendon research, biomechanics, tissue engineering, developmental biology, embryonic stem cells, transcriptional profiling, artificial intelligence (AI), breast cancer diagnostics, immune-related adverse events (IRAEs), cancer immunotherapy, neonatal tissue regeneration, rotator cuff repair, and murine models.

Central sensitization explores how heightened pain perception post-endometriosis surgery can be assessed using the Central Sensitization Inventory (CSI). This research indicates that persistent pain may be influenced by factors beyond endometriosis itself. In tendon research, advancements in biomechanics, tissue engineering, and developmental biology are highlighted, focusing on tendon cell fate and the limitations of current methodologies. The study of embryonic stem cells reveals the effective induction of tendon and fibrocartilage cells through TGF_ and hedgehog pathways, with retinoic acid signaling playing a crucial role. AI is investigated for its potential to enhance breast cancer diagnostics through improved ultrasound accuracy, while the study of IRAEs emphasizes the role of radiologists in identifying complications from cancer immunotherapy. Additionally, neonatal tissue regeneration research shows superior healing capabilities in neonatal tissues, particularly in rotator cuff repair, where neonatal tendon progenitor cells may improve recovery outcomes. Murine models further elucidate the challenges of tendon healing and the impact of scar formation on functional integrity.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Drosophila tracheal system, cellular morphogenesis, tubulogenesis, neurovascular unit, glial cells, mTOR-vATPase axis, CCM3 genes, Hippo pathway, osmoregulation, and genetic interactions.

The research investigates the mechanisms regulating tube formation and morphology in the Drosophila tracheal system, focusing on the mTOR-vATPase axis and its role in apical membrane expansion. It examines the genetic factors affecting tube integrity, such as the ichor mutant and mutations in oak gall and conjoined, which influence tube shape and branching. The study of cellular morphogenesis highlights the genetic separability of cell size and branch complexity, linking genes to the TOR and Hippo pathways. Tubulogenesis is further explored in C. elegans, emphasizing osmoregulation's role in seamless tube growth. The research on CCM3 genes reveals their importance in regulating tube morphogenesis and highlights the utility of mosaic animals for studying gene functions. Additionally, the role of glial cells in the neurovascular unit's development is examined, indicating their critical influence on neuronal and vascular organization and potential implications for neurovascular diseases. The GckIII pathway's interactions with Ccm3 and metabolic enzymes are also explored, linking it to tracheal morphogenesis and vascular disease mechanisms.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: clonal hematopoiesis (CH), acute myeloid leukemia (AML), myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs), chromatin dynamics, chromatin architecture, hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs), and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

Clonal hematopoiesis (CH) focuses on the genetic variants that increase risks for malignancies and cardiovascular diseases, particularly influenced by aging. In acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the interaction of mutations like NPM1 and cohesin mutations affects the transcriptome, revealing potential therapeutic targets. Myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPNs) research identifies recurrent mutations, such as JAK2, indicating complex pathogenesis. Chromatin dynamics studies, particularly involving SMARCA5, highlight its role in chromatin organization without affecting transcriptional activity. The role of chromatin architecture in hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs) emphasizes the importance of YY1 and SMC3 in gene regulation and differentiation. Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) research underscores the impact of cohesin mutations on hematopoietic stem cell function and lineage commitment, revealing the need for targeted therapies in cohesin mutant MDS/AML. Overall, these studies explore the intricate relationships between genetic mutations, chromatin organization, and hematopoietic malignancies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: far-UVC light disinfection, surgical site infection prevention, biventricular pacing, cardiac surgery techniques, UV radiation monitoring, cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) optimization, and transtelephonic monitoring (TTM) in pediatric patients.

Far-UVC light disinfection focuses on using 224 nm and 207 nm wavelengths to effectively combat MRSA and reduce surgical site infections, providing a safer alternative for patients and staff. Biventricular pacing research investigates its role in enhancing cardiac output and improving hemodynamics in patients post-surgery, including novel access techniques and predictors of response to pacing. The cardiac surgery techniques encompass innovations in managing congenital defects and cardiovascular diseases, along with minimally invasive interventions. UV radiation monitoring employs Gafchromic EBT3 film to assess UV exposure, critical for health safety. CRT optimization involves developing a classification system to improve therapy effectiveness through quantitative evaluation. Lastly, TTM research evaluates its efficacy in pediatric patients with epicardial pacemakers, comparing malfunction detection rates with transvenous systems.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: liver cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), cholangiocarcinoma, cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), immunotherapy, liver diseases, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), liver fibrosis, hepatic stellate cells (HSCs), metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD), and signaling pathways in liver disease.

The researcher investigates liver cancer, particularly HCC and cholangiocarcinoma, highlighting the distinct roles of fibroblasts in tumor regulation and growth. In HCC, the TAZ-TEAD2 pathway is targeted for therapeutic strategies, while cholangiocarcinoma's rising incidence prompts exploration of immunotherapy and immune cell diversity. Studies on CAFs reveal their dual roles in tumor promotion and suppression, with type I collagen influencing tumor spread. The research also delves into liver diseases like NASH and MASLD, examining the interplay between hepatocytes and HSCs in fibrogenesis. Techniques for genetic labeling and knockout in HSCs are reviewed to understand their roles in liver homeostasis and disease. Finally, the identification of signaling pathways, such as ATF3/HES1/CEBPA/OPN, offers potential therapeutic targets for liver fibrosis associated with MASLD.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: high-dose radiation therapy (HDRT), tumor vasculature, Notch signaling, neuroblastoma, anti-PD1 therapy, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), pediatric oncology, tuberous sclerosis complex, pigmented epithelioid melanocytoma (PEM), and genetic sequencing in melanocytic tumors. 

The research on HDRT investigates its effects on tumor vasculature and Notch signaling, revealing how HDRT alters Notch1 levels and endothelial cell-pericyte interactions in neuroblastoma, suggesting new therapeutic targets. In neuroblastoma, ATF5's role in metastasis and the potential of TFAP4 as a therapeutic target are highlighted, along with the implications of HIF prolyl hydroxylase inhibitors. The use of anti-PD1 therapy in pediatric HCC raises concerns about graft rejection post-liver transplantation, while the case of tuberous sclerosis complex emphasizes the need to monitor adverse effects of everolimus. Additionally, the report on PEM underscores the importance of genetic sequencing to differentiate between melanocytic tumors and identifies novel genetic fusions, enhancing the understanding of tumor biology and potential therapeutic targets.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: germline mutations, somatic mutations, DNA repair, evolutionary genetics, population genetics, pandemic response, aneuploidy, and genetic factors in social equality.

Germline mutations are a significant focus, with studies revealing a paternal bias in mutation rates across various species, indicating that mutations accumulate more in males post-sexual differentiation. Somatic mutations are explored in relation to DNA repair mechanisms, with findings showing that certain mutation signatures are linked to replication errors and DNA repair inefficiencies. The research on evolutionary genetics includes the rapid evolution of PRDM9 and its role in double strand break repair, as well as the implications of genetic factors on fitness and trait evolution. Population genetics studies aim to understand coral bleaching responses and the variability of polygenic scores across ancestry groups. The response to pandemics highlights the risks faced by essential workers, advocating for targeted interventions. The study of aneuploidy introduces TroX, a method for analyzing trisomic products, while discussions on genetic factors in social equality emphasize the broader implications of genetic research on societal issues.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pediatric intensive care, Klebsiella pneumoniae, immune responses, antibiotic resistance, neutrophil interactions, COVID-19, and gastrointestinal symptoms in children.

Pediatric intensive care focuses on optimizing diagnostic strategies in the PICU, particularly evaluating the utility of serial tracheal aspirate cultures for infection monitoring. Research on Klebsiella pneumoniae emphasizes understanding immune responses and resistance mechanisms, revealing how lipid A modifications and interleukin-10 influence infection outcomes. The study of immune responses also includes the dual role of interferon-lambda in pneumonia pathogenesis. Neutrophil interactions with carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae highlight challenges in bacterial clearance and the role of L-arginine supplementation in enhancing immune responses. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the researcher examined the adaptation of pediatric critical care practices and identified gastrointestinal symptoms as significant in a novel inflammatory syndrome in children. Overall, this research underscores the complexity of managing multidrug-resistant infections and the need for innovative therapeutic approaches in both pediatric and adult critical care settings.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: gastroenterology, COVID-19 impact on medical training, esophageal cancer, three-dimensional organoids, immunology, venous thrombus resolution, and gastrointestinal oncology.

Gastroenterology is a primary focus, particularly regarding fellowship programs and their adaptation during the COVID-19 pandemic, addressing challenges in training and patient care. The impact of COVID-19 on educational activities is critically examined, emphasizing the need for innovative strategies to restore pre-pandemic practices. In esophageal cancer research, three-dimensional organoids are utilized to model disease mechanisms and therapy resistance, facilitating personalized medicine. The researcher is exploring high-throughput genomic screening and co-culture techniques to enhance understanding of esophageal cancer progression. Immunology is also a key area, specifically the role of CD4 and CD8 positive T cells in venous thrombus resolution, highlighting their importance in inflammatory responses. Lastly, advancements in gastrointestinal oncology are noted through the study of oncogenic transformation and transplantation protocols of human-derived gastric organoids, contributing to the understanding of gastric cancer mechanisms and treatment strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: retinal development, neurogenesis, albinism, Wnt signaling, glaucoma, genetic background, diencephalon patterning, and transcription factors. 

Retinal development is a primary focus, investigating how factors like CyclinD2 and Lhx9 influence neurogenic output and the formation of specific retinal cell types. Neurogenesis studies reveal the importance of Lhx9 in generating nitric oxide-synthesizing amacrine cells and highlight the roles of LIM-homeodomain transcription factors in retinal cell subtype specification. Albinism research uncovers the impact of disrupted melanogenesis on retinal ganglion cell projections and identifies dysregulation in the Wnt signaling pathway, which is crucial for retinal differentiation. Glaucoma studies explore how genetic background affects susceptibility to elevated intraocular pressure and ocular abnormalities in Lmx1b mutant mice, revealing potential genetic modifiers. Additionally, the research on diencephalon patterning emphasizes the role of Barhl2 in regulating Shh expression, which is essential for establishing progenitor cell identities and proper neural connections during development.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: airway epithelium regulation, lung development, multiciliogenesis, signaling pathways in lung biology, vitamin A deficiency, and stem cell dynamics. 

Airway epithelium regulation focuses on mechanisms like Tnrc6a's role in ciliogenesis and Notch signaling's impact on airway integrity. Lung development research includes Sox9's role in snake lung morphogenesis and the effects of vitamin A deficiency among ethnic groups, highlighting genetic influences on health. Multiciliogenesis is explored through E2F4's interaction with centriole replication components and its organizing role in centriole amplification. Signaling pathways such as Hippo-Yap/Taz and FGF10 are critical for understanding cellular behavior, angiogenesis, and lung homeostasis. Additionally, the research on stem cell dynamics reveals heterogeneity in basal cells and their responses to injury, as well as the transition of alveolar type 2 cells during regeneration. Lastly, the implications of intravitreal bevacizumab treatment on respiratory outcomes in preterm infants underscore the need for further investigation into its effects on lung health.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: lung transplantation, liver transplantation, bioengineering, tissue engineering, stem cell biology, cardiac tissue engineering, drug delivery systems, and organ-on-a-chip technology. 

Lung transplantation research focuses on enhancing donor lung viability through cross-circulation techniques and bioengineering methods to recover damaged lungs and improve preservation. Liver transplantation studies involve veno-arterial-venous cross-circulation for maintaining liver function. Bioengineering efforts include creating vascularized lung grafts and developing hydrofoam sealants for pulmonary air leaks. In tissue engineering, advancements are made in cartilage and bone grafts, with a focus on vascularization and biomimetic approaches. Stem cell biology research explores the regeneration of hematopoietic stem cells and the effects of microenvironmental factors on stem cell differentiation. Cardiac tissue engineering investigates the role of macrophages in engineered tissues and the development of tissue-engineered heart valves. Drug delivery systems aim to enhance therapeutic efficacy through targeted mechanisms. Lastly, organ-on-a-chip technology is utilized to model complex organ interactions and study drug responses, advancing the understanding of disease mechanisms and therapeutic strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: visual motion circuitry, synaptic responses in neurons, sensory processing in insects, chromatic visual stimuli design, chromatic encoding mechanisms, hue-selective neurons, and neuronal circuits in sensory perception.

Visual motion circuitry research focuses on temporal contrast adaptation in Drosophila, revealing that ON-pathway neurons, particularly the Mi1 neuron, exhibit strong adaptation, enhancing motion estimates and affecting downstream motion responses. The study of synaptic responses investigates how subthreshold membrane potential modulates synaptic activity in layer 5 pyramidal neurons, highlighting the role of voltage-sensitive calcium channels in enhancing synaptic calcium signals.

Sensory processing in insects examines the flexible filtering properties of Drosophila's motion detection system and specialized microcircuits that enhance feature detection. Research on chromatic visual stimuli design introduces methods for creating tailored stimuli based on animal photoreceptor sensitivities, promoting uniform experimental approaches. Chromatic encoding mechanisms explore how Drosophila processes spectral information through antagonistic responses and a dual pathway model. Finally, the study of hue-selective neurons provides insights into the circuit-level analysis of color processing, emphasizing the complexity of sensory circuits in the fly brain that govern various visual modalities.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurogenesis, neural stem cells, chronic stress, psychiatric disorders, humor and melancholy, norepinephrine signaling, serotonin signaling, and emotional regulation.

Neurogenesis is a key focus, particularly how early life experiences influence adult hippocampal neurogenesis and the dentate gyrus (DG) development. The role of neural stem cells is emphasized, showing that ablation during critical early life periods significantly reduces the adult stem cell reservoir. Chronic stress is investigated for its contributions to psychiatric disorders, with Kruppel-like factor 9 (Klf9) identified as a critical mediator of stress responses and resilience. The intersection of humor and melancholy is explored, suggesting humor as a coping mechanism during sadness. Norepinephrine and serotonin signaling are examined for their roles in emotional function and mood-related behaviors, highlighting their influence on anxiety and depression. The research underscores the importance of understanding gene expression in the DG and the complex dynamics of serotonin receptors to address antidepressant resistance and improve interventions for mood and anxiety disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: flapper skate conservation, spinal cord research, neuronal analysis, oceanography, and citizen science. 

Flapper skate conservation focuses on the successful incubation of Dipturus intermedius eggs in captivity, emphasizing the critical need for conservation efforts due to their extended embryonic period and vulnerability to disturbances. Spinal cord research involves the development of SpineRacks and SpinalJ tools, which facilitate the organized analysis of neurons in a 3D reference atlas of the mouse spinal cord, enabling high-throughput spatial analyses and comparisons across studies. Neuronal analysis is enhanced through the construction of a comprehensive atlas and software that standardizes the examination of neuronal distributions. Oceanography research explores the innovative application of benthic animal-borne sensors, particularly in studying the flapper skate, to validate ocean models and address data gaps. Lastly, the role of citizen science is highlighted as a valuable component in enhancing model accuracy and expanding the understanding of aquatic ecosystems through community engagement and data collection.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cachexia, breast cancer, metal-ion transport, lung cancer, TNF-_ inhibitors, chemotherapy, osimertinib resistance, and brain metastases.

Cachexia is a significant focus, particularly its association with breast cancer, where aberrant expression of the metal-ion transporter Zip14 in muscle has been linked to muscle wasting in a Bard1-deficient mouse model. This research highlights the role of altered metal-ion homeostasis in cachexia, especially in triple-negative breast cancer. In lung cancer, the researcher investigates the efficacy of the TNF-_ inhibitor certolizumab in combination with chemotherapy, demonstrating its potential in managing stage IV lung adenocarcinomas. Additionally, the mechanisms of osimertinib resistance in EGFR-mutant lung cancer are explored, with findings indicating that high levels of S100A9 contribute to brain metastasis. This research emphasizes the S100A9-ALDH1A1-retinoic acid signaling pathway as a potential target for preventing brain relapses, showcasing the intricate relationship between cancer progression, treatment resistance, and cachexia.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: surgical education, early specialization in surgery, medical student assessment, surgical outcomes, and surgical procedures. 

Surgical education is a primary focus, emphasizing the evaluation of longitudinal curricula for medical students to enhance training and preparedness for future surgeons. The research also investigates early specialization in surgery, examining trainees' perceptions of its impact on their training experiences, career decisions, and surgical skills development. In the realm of medical student assessment, the researcher explores adaptations necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly the shift towards virtual learning and the need for new assessment strategies. Surgical outcomes are analyzed through meta-analyses that highlight long-term mortality risks associated with specific surgical procedures, such as lower extremity amputation and abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. Additionally, the researcher investigates the effectiveness of observing surgeries or online videos in enhancing surgical performance and evaluates a new written examination designed to assess surgical knowledge and clinical skills among medical students during their clerkship.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: GABAA receptors, airway smooth muscle (ASM), bronchoconstrictive diseases, uterine smooth muscle (USM), tocolytic therapies, calcium-activated chloride channels, TMEM16A, pluripotent stem cells (PSCs), lung bioengineering, chronic inflammation, and immune responses in asthma.

The research explores GABAA receptors, particularly their role in ASM relaxation and the potential for treating bronchoconstrictive diseases like asthma. It highlights the dual role of GABA in airway physiology and its regulation by protein kinase A. In uterine smooth muscle, the focus is on enhancing tocolytic therapies by targeting anoctamin 1 (ANO1) to improve relaxation during preterm labor. The role of TMEM16A in ASM contraction is examined, with findings suggesting its antagonists may serve as therapeutic targets for asthma and cystic fibrosis. The innovative use of PSCs in lung bioengineering addresses the challenge of creating functional lungs for transplantation. Additionally, the anti-inflammatory properties of ginger and its component 6-shogaol are investigated for their effects on lung inflammation, while the immune response modulation by GABAA receptor _4-subunits in asthma is also a significant area of study.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: structural biology, protein dynamics, cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM), tau aggregation, neurodegenerative diseases, molecular machines, and electron microscopy techniques. Structural biology is a primary focus, emphasizing advanced imaging techniques to study protein conformational dynamics and interactions. Protein dynamics research involves exploring the nanomechanics of amyloid structures and their stabilization mechanisms. Cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) is a key method employed to achieve near-atomic resolution in reconstructing protein complexes and analyzing tau filaments, revealing how posttranslational modifications influence their structure. Tau aggregation studies investigate the self-assembly of tau proteins in Alzheimer's disease and related tauopathies, providing insights into disease mechanisms and biomarker development. Neurodegenerative diseases research includes examining TMEM106B and _-synuclein dynamics, contributing to understanding amyloid fibril properties. Molecular machines research focuses on the structural dynamics of receptors and efflux pumps, elucidating mechanisms of cellular transport. Lastly, innovative electron microscopy techniques are developed to enhance imaging capabilities, enabling the observation of transient molecular interactions.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: HIV prevention, transgender health, intersectionality, mental health, healthcare access, stigma, peer-led interventions, and psychological assessment. 

HIV prevention focuses on strategies to enhance testing and PrEP uptake among transgender women, particularly in marginalized communities. Transgender health encompasses studies addressing barriers to care, including gender-based violence and socio-ecological factors affecting health outcomes. Intersectionality examines the systemic inequities faced by underrepresented groups, emphasizing cultural humility in mentorship. Mental health research highlights the emotional distress and stigma experienced by transgender and gender diverse individuals, including the development of the Psychological Gender Affirmation Scale to support clinical practices. Healthcare access investigates the impact of discrimination and gender-affirming practices on care engagement for transgender women of color. Stigma is explored through studies on anticipated stigma affecting healthcare communication. Peer-led interventions, such as the "Entre Nosotras" initiative, aim to improve health outcomes by fostering community support. Lastly, psychological assessment research contributes to understanding the unique experiences of transgender individuals, including those who experience pregnancy post-transitioning. Together, these areas address the multifaceted challenges faced by transgender women in healthcare and HIV prevention.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: maternal health, adolescent pregnancy, postpartum complications, maternal infections, and healthcare policy. Maternal health is a central focus, with investigations into delivery hospitalization trends among adolescents aged 11-19, highlighting the unique challenges and risk factors affecting this demographic. The research on postpartum complications specifically addresses maternal sepsis, evaluating prevalence, clinical risk factors, and outcomes related to readmissions. Additionally, the study of maternal infections encompasses the examination of hepatitis C virus (HCV) infections, cystic fibrosis (CF) complications, and influenza during delivery hospitalizations, providing insights into their impact on maternal health outcomes. Lastly, the research emphasizes healthcare policy, aiming to inform practices and initiatives that improve support for young mothers and enhance maternal and neonatal health.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: bariatric surgery, obesity management, metabolic processes, long-term effectiveness and safety of surgical procedures, sex-specific metabolic outcomes, and intermittent fasting.

Bariatric surgery is a primary focus, with investigations into its mechanistic foundations to uncover insights for innovative, non-invasive obesity treatments. The research aims to understand how these procedures impact metabolic processes and weight regulation, identifying therapeutic targets for non-surgical interventions. The long-term effectiveness and safety of various bariatric procedures are also explored using a PCORnet cohort, addressing the need for comprehensive data on their outcomes to inform patient choices. Additionally, the study of sex-specific metabolic outcomes following sleeve gastrectomy and intermittent fasting in mice reveals significant differences, particularly highlighting better results in females regarding weight loss maintenance and metabolic health. This suggests that sex differences should inform obesity treatment strategies, and further clinical studies are recommended to validate these findings.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: genetics, proline biosynthesis, neurogenesis, glaucoma, retinal function, auditory function, mitochondrial function, neuroprotection, metabolic disorders, neuroinflammation, and RNA sequencing. 

In genetics, the focus is on the roles of Pycr1 and Pycr2 in proline biosynthesis, with implications for human disorders like Cutis Laxa and hypomyelinating leukodystrophy. The neurogenesis research highlights the regulatory role of CyclinD2 in retinal ganglion cells, particularly in albinism, and the potential for pharmacological interventions to enhance neurogenesis. Glaucoma research investigates the genetic factors such as GLIS1 and LMX1B mutations affecting intraocular pressure and neurodegeneration. The study of retinal and auditory functions emphasizes the importance of ATP8A2 in sensory systems and the impact of metabolic disturbances on glaucoma. Mitochondrial function is explored through clinical trials assessing nicotinamide and pyruvate for neuroprotection in glaucoma. The researcher also examines neuroinflammation's role in optic nerve degeneration and utilizes RNA sequencing to analyze microglial responses in glaucoma models, revealing insights into the underlying mechanisms of neurodegeneration.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: healthcare data interoperability, machine learning, digital biobanks, data quality assessment, clinical decision support systems, genomic education, natural language processing (NLP), evidence retrieval, clinical trials, and artificial intelligence (AI). 

Healthcare data interoperability focuses on improving patient data representation through methods like aligning OMOP CDM with Phenopackets. Machine learning is utilized to analyze outcomes in autologous breast reconstruction and to enhance data quality in electronic health records (EHRs). Digital biobanks, particularly in dermatology, are explored for their genetic insights. Data quality assessment methods address coding biases and completeness in EHRs and clinical trials. Clinical decision support systems for cancer therapy and frameworks for genomic education are also developed. NLP is leveraged for clinical trial eligibility prescreening, rare disease annotation, and constructing disease similarity networks. Evidence retrieval is enhanced through models like PICOX for extracting PICO entities and normalizing complex interventions. AI applications in healthcare include transforming eligibility criteria into database queries and optimizing clinical study criteria, with a focus on trustworthiness and clinician perceptions of AI tools.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Bayesian inference, cognitive control, schizophrenia, reinforcement learning, perceptual disturbances, psychosis, neuromelanin-sensitive MRI (NM-MRI), dopamine function, addiction, and depression.

Bayesian inference is investigated through the parieto-occipital cortex's role in decision-making, highlighting how subjective posterior probabilities are updated with prior beliefs and new evidence. Cognitive control studies reveal temporal coding in the prefrontal cortex during conflict processing. In schizophrenia, the research links delusions to inferential abnormalities, suggesting that increased information-seeking relates to delusion severity. Reinforcement learning is explored through changes in corticostriatal connectivity during task learning.

Perceptual disturbances in psychosis are examined, focusing on introspective agents' ability to recognize perception distortions and the impact of hallucination proneness on decision-making. NM-MRI studies reveal dopaminergic dysfunction in psychosis and potential biomarkers for psychiatric disorders. The role of dopamine in addiction is explored, particularly in cocaine addiction and its effects on utility prediction errors. Lastly, the research distinguishes between risk and resilience in depression, analyzing neural correlates in individuals with familial major depressive disorder.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: white matter integrity, multiple sclerosis (MS), implantable electronic stimulation devices, neuropsychological effects of soccer heading, hippocampal volume, chronic pain, hormonal contraceptives, stroke imaging, arterial spin labeling (ASL), neuroimaging techniques, and respiratory-gating methods. 

White matter integrity research focuses on its implications in depression among older adults with MS, microstructural changes in combat veterans, and chronic hydrocephalus, utilizing diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) for analysis. Multiple sclerosis studies investigate life-space mobility and falls, exploring correlations between mobility scores and fall risk across MS subtypes. The effects of soccer heading on cognitive performance and neuropsychological function are examined, revealing adverse impacts and gender differences. Hippocampal volume studies link brain structure to apathy, chronic pain, and memory performance, emphasizing the role of hippocampal subfields. Research on hormonal contraceptives highlights brain changes and structural MRI findings. Stroke imaging advancements include ASL as a non-contrast alternative for assessing ischemic penumbra. Neuroimaging techniques like DTI are crucial for detecting brain injuries, while respiratory-gating methods aim to improve understanding of obstructive sleep apnea.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: clinical data infrastructure, data quality, COVID-19 research, drug-resistant epilepsy, cervical neoplasms, electronic health records (EHRs), vaccination effectiveness, myocardial infarction, social media in medical studies, immunization data exchange, and infectious disease surveillance.

Clinical data infrastructure focuses on developing sustainable models for multi-institutional clinical data repositories, emphasizing stakeholder inclusion and data governance. Data quality research addresses the challenges of wearable device data and enhances tools like the Achilles Heel for assessing large healthcare datasets. COVID-19 research includes vaccine effectiveness studies and characterizing hospitalized patients using EHR data. Drug-resistant epilepsy emphasizes comprehensive neurodiagnostic evaluations and longitudinal data on referrals. The cervical neoplasms study compares cancer risks between different contraceptive methods. EHRs research involves standardizing clinical note titles and harmonizing lab data retrieval. Vaccination effectiveness studies assess mRNA vaccines against variants and booster strategies. Myocardial infarction research targets young adults, while social media's role in participant recruitment is evaluated. Immunization data exchange studies focus on urban children, and infectious disease surveillance explores methods using unstructured health data.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: bone metabolism, muscle metabolism, signaling pathways, osteocalcin, immune functions, and metabolic regulation. 

Bone metabolism is explored through studies on the interplay between bone remodeling and energy metabolism, highlighting leptin's role and the implications of hematological conditions on osteoporosis. Muscle metabolism focuses on the role of interleukin-6 (IL-6) signaling in enhancing bone remodeling and skeletal muscle hypertrophy. Signaling pathways are examined through various mechanisms, such as phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) signaling for muscle growth and the regulatory roles of HDAC4 and Tsc2 in osteoblast development. Osteocalcin is identified as a critical hormone influencing energy metabolism, cognitive function, and male fertility, with significant implications for maternal and offspring health. Immune functions are investigated through the role of PTPN2 in type 1 diabetes and IL-33 in type 2 immunity. Finally, metabolic regulation encompasses the effects of adiponectin on _-cell expansion during pregnancy and the interactions between osteocalcin and insulin in glucose metabolism.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), cardiovascular health, sleep, medication adherence, air pollution, psychological impacts of acute coronary syndrome (ACS), behavior change interventions, climate change, health inequities, and racial/ethnic disparities in cardiovascular disease (CVD).

Research on PTSD focuses on its bidirectional relationship with sleep duration and its prevalence in stroke and transient ischemic attack survivors, alongside its associations with cardiovascular health risks. Cardiovascular health studies investigate the impact of air pollution, particularly nitrogen dioxide, on myocardial infarction and the psychosocial factors influencing health outcomes post-ACS. Medication adherence research highlights the mediating role of medication concerns in stroke survivors. Behavior change interventions are examined through the CLIMBR framework, emphasizing mechanisms for successful health behavior changes, particularly in the context of climate change and health inequities. Additionally, studies on racial/ethnic disparities reveal higher CVD risks among sexual minorities, with an emphasis on the psychosocial factors affecting cardiovascular health and the need for targeted interventions. Overall, this research underscores the complex interplay between psychological, environmental, and social factors in health outcomes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: kidney health, urinary tract infections (UTIs), acute kidney injury (AKI), renal biomarkers, iron metabolism in kidneys, proteinuria, transcription factors in renal function, immune defense mechanisms in the urinary system, and cryoelectron microscopy of kidney proteins.

Kidney health research focuses on epithelial injury and its implications for transplantation outcomes. UTI studies emphasize innate bacteriostatic mechanisms and the potential of urinary NGAL as a diagnostic marker. AKI research investigates its mechanisms, highlighting the limitations of serum creatinine as a diagnostic tool and exploring mitochondrial iron transporters' roles. Renal biomarkers like urinary NGAL are examined for their potential in identifying infections and sepsis. Iron metabolism studies explore ferroportin's role in renal iron recycling and its effects on ischemic AKI. The significance of proteinuria, particularly albuminuria, in chronic kidney disease is critically analyzed. Research on transcription factors, particularly TFCP2L1, reveals their importance in maintaining kidney function. Immune defense mechanisms in the urinary system are explored, showing how sodium gradients trigger immune responses against bacterial infections. Lastly, cryoelectron microscopy provides insights into the structure and function of LRP2, enhancing understanding of kidney-related diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: membrane trafficking, neurodevelopmental disorders, dendrite morphogenesis, neuromuscular systems, proprioception, nociception, genome engineering, chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, immune defects in Fragile X syndrome, dendritic diversification, axon-axon interactions, and neuronal recognition.

Membrane trafficking is explored in relation to neurodevelopmental disorders, particularly how GARP regulates sterol transfer necessary for dendrite remodeling. Dendrite morphogenesis studies in C. elegans reveal a ligand-receptor complex guiding dendritic growth. The neuromuscular system research focuses on Drosophila larvae's escape behaviors, detailing muscle activity and proprioceptive system dynamics. Nociceptive interneurons are identified, linking sensory inputs to motor responses. A novel genome engineering technique allows scarless modifications in Drosophila, enhancing genetic editing efficiency. Research on chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy highlights integrins' protective roles, while delta 2 tubulin's accumulation is linked to axonal degeneration. Immune defects in Fragile X syndrome are examined through Fmr1 mutants, and dendritic diversification is regulated by a transcriptional hierarchy. Axon-axon interactions are characterized in sensory circuitry, and protocadherins are studied for their role in dendritic self-avoidance, ensuring proper neuronal wiring.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: bacterial pathogenesis, immune response, autoimmune diseases, heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), gene therapy, and respiratory infections. 

Bacterial pathogenesis is a key focus, particularly regarding Streptococcus pneumoniae, which causes pneumonia and meningitis, highlighting the role of B cells, dendritic cells, and T cells in developing immunity. The interplay between these immune cells and the virulence factors of S. pneumoniae is crucial for understanding infection control. In the realm of autoimmune diseases, the researcher emphasizes HO-1 as a therapeutic target, exploring gene and pharmaceutical therapies that modulate HO-1 and its product, carbon monoxide, to provide immunoregulatory effects in conditions like multiple sclerosis and lupus. The adaptation mechanisms of Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Klebsiella pneumoniae to evade innate immune clearance in respiratory infections are also examined, detailing their strategies against host defenses and the implications for chronic conditions like cystic fibrosis and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: SARS-CoV-2 variants, antibody evasion, antiviral resistance, protease inhibitors, viral adaptation, and parvovirus interactions. 

SARS-CoV-2 variants, particularly the Omicron subvariants BQ, XBB, and BA.2.75, exhibit significant antibody evasion, necessitating new interventions due to their enhanced transmissibility and resistance to neutralization by vaccinated individuals. Antibody evasion is a critical focus, with studies showing reduced effectiveness of monoclonal antibodies against these subvariants. Antiviral resistance is explored through the evolution of SARS-CoV-2, particularly concerning nirmatrelvir and its associated mutations in the 3CL protease, which may inform next-generation drug development. The research on protease inhibitors highlights the identification of promising compounds like coronastat and GC376, showcasing their potential against SARS-CoV-2. Viral adaptation studies reveal how rapid genomic changes in viruses like HPIV-3 can affect their properties, emphasizing the need to consider these changes in therapeutic contexts. Additionally, the interactions between parvovirus capsids and transferrin receptors are investigated, providing insights into viral infection dynamics.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurodevelopmental disorders, genetics, congenital anomalies, pediatric intensive care, cardiomyopathy, artificial intelligence in medical genetics, genetic counseling, and educational interventions in genetics.

Neurodevelopmental disorders are a primary focus, particularly the exploration of gait patterns in children with PPP2R5D-related disorders and the characterization of HIVEP2-related disorders. Genetics is extensively studied, including copy number variations in 16p11.2, associations of FRYL variants with developmental delays, and the identification of novel variants linked to various syndromes. Congenital anomalies are investigated through genetic variants affecting conditions like congenital diaphragmatic hernia. In pediatric intensive care, rapid exome sequencing is being utilized to improve genomic assessments. Research on dilated cardiomyopathy emphasizes the role of the C10orf71 gene and its potential therapeutic targets. Artificial intelligence's role in medical genetics is examined, highlighting the need for updated training programs. Genetic counseling efforts focus on effective communication and educational strategies, including web-based interventions to facilitate the return of genetic results and address inequities in variant interpretation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: mental health, violence, schizophrenia, psychosis, neurobiology, genetic factors, antipsychotic treatments, psychedelic drugs, and glutamatergic drugs. 

In the field of mental health, the researcher has analyzed mass murders, identifying demographic patterns and mental illness prevalence among perpetrators. Their work on schizophrenia includes exploring neurodegenerative models, genetic factors, and treatment approaches, emphasizing the role of dopamine and glutamate in symptom severity and cognitive dysfunction. The psychosis research focuses on neurobiological predictors and the impact of untreated psychosis duration on outcomes. Genetic studies have identified specific alleles linked to treatment responses and adverse effects. The investigation into antipsychotic treatments reveals insights into metabolic effects and genetic influences on drug efficacy. Furthermore, the researcher examines the therapeutic potential of psychedelic drugs and glutamatergic drugs, evaluating their effects on symptoms and brain activity in clinical trials. Overall, their work underscores the complexity of mental health disorders and the need for innovative treatment strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: circular RNAs (circRNAs), diabetes, metal-organic frameworks, childhood trauma, religious attendance and health, Huntington's disease, neuronal activity, social genetics, loneliness, cognitive function, oral health, testosterone dynamics, and hemodynamic responses in the visual cortex.

Circular RNAs (circRNAs) are explored for their regulatory roles in gene expression and cellular functions, with studies validating their sequences and identifying splice variants. Research on diabetes focuses on circular intronic RNAs from the insulin gene and their expression in pancreatic _-cells. The development of a phthalimide-functionalized metal-organic framework serves as a fluorescent sensor for hydrazine, showcasing applications in live-cell imaging. Investigations into childhood trauma reveal its long-term psychological impacts. The relationship between religious attendance and health is examined in older adults, alongside studies on Huntington's disease, where dexamethasone shows therapeutic potential.

Neuronal activity research utilizes calcium sensors to record activity patterns in freely-moving mice. Social genetics studies the influence of genes on cognitive function and relationship quality among older adults, while loneliness and chronic stressors are linked to health outcomes. Oral health's impact on aging is analyzed, and testosterone dynamics in older adults reveal gender-specific influences on relationship quality. Lastly, hemodynamic responses in the visual cortex are studied, highlighting the effects of reward and task engagement on vascular responses.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: COVID-19, tissue immunity, pancreatic islet autotransplantation, tumorigenesis, leukemia, antibody responses, platelet storage, cytomegalovirus transmission, and autoimmune interactions.

Research on COVID-19 focuses on age-related risks and alveolar injury, revealing that type 2 alveolar epithelial cell deficiency may increase vulnerability in older individuals. Tissue immunity research emphasizes the influence of aging and climate change on T cell responses, proposing strategies to enhance tissue immunity. The study of pancreatic islet autotransplantation post-total pancreatectomy shows improvements in narcotic and insulin independence, suggesting further investigation in malignancy cases. Tumorigenesis research identifies Zfx as a facilitator in skin basal cell carcinoma and medulloblastoma, while its role in leukemia highlights its potential as a therapeutic target. Antibody response studies reveal differing responses to SARS-CoV-2 in children and adults, with children showing reduced neutralizing activity. Platelet storage research indicates lower plasma protein levels in stored platelets, while cytomegalovirus transmission studies stress the need for "CMV-safe" blood products. Lastly, autoimmune interactions are explored in pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, contributing to understanding their pathophysiology.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: diabetes management, cancer immunology, agricultural pest management, medical education, otolaryngology, microbiology, machine learning, cardiology, and environmental science. 

Diabetes management focuses on glycaemic variability, emphasizing the importance of metrics like coefficient of variation for glucose. Research explores insulin therapies, including the evolution of insulin formulations and the impact of GLP-1 receptor agonists. Cancer immunology investigates CD200's role in tumor microenvironments and its therapeutic potential. Agricultural pest management examines the effects of insecticide programs on pest control and profitability. Medical education includes the development of e-learning platforms for ENT and assessing junior doctors' learning needs. In otolaryngology, studies compare teaching methods and address self-harm services. Microbiology research reveals correlations between precipitation and microbial concentrations in drinking water. Machine learning applications include undiagnosed diabetes detection via retinal images and neural networks for diabetic retinopathy. Cardiology research explores aortic stenosis risk factors and management pathways. Lastly, environmental science studies the climate influences on endangered species like the Kemp's ridley sea turtle.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: perinatal depression, climate change and mental health, neighborhood stressors and sleep quality, immigration and mental health, maternal childhood maltreatment, brain development, emotion regulation, ADHD, prenatal interventions, and parent training.

Perinatal depression is explored through system-level approaches that involve various stakeholders and interventions. The impact of climate change on mental health is examined, focusing on the psychological effects of environmental changes. The relationship between neighborhood stressors and sleep quality among Puerto Rican young adults highlights the significance of environmental factors on health outcomes. The intersection of immigration, ethnicity, and mental health reveals how identity struggles and discrimination affect immigrant populations, emphasizing the need for culturally sensitive mental health strategies. 

Research on maternal childhood maltreatment investigates its intergenerational effects on brain development, particularly increased fronto-limbic connectivity in sons of maltreated mothers. Emotion regulation difficulties in children are linked to maternal distress and ADHD, with studies addressing the impact of prenatal interventions on maternal mental health and offspring outcomes. Parent training is shown to reduce ADHD symptoms, while early fathering is identified as a predictor of later psychosocial functioning in children with behavior problems.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: sedentary behavior, physical activity, health monitoring, cardiovascular health, health disparities, and children's health behaviors. Sedentary behavior research focuses on its health implications, particularly its correlation with cardiovascular disease and mortality, and the need for targeted interventions among specific populations like Hispanic/Latino and African American adults. Physical activity studies examine measurement reliability of wearable devices, changes in health behaviors during the COVID-19 pandemic, and the relationship between exercise and various health outcomes, including anxiety and hypertension. Health monitoring research emphasizes the use of accelerometers and ecological momentary assessments to capture habitual activity levels and monitor cardiovascular health. Cardiovascular health investigations explore the effects of air pollution, medication adherence post-acute coronary syndromes, and the impact of lifestyle factors on hypertension. Health disparities research highlights the prevalence of conditions like masked hypertension in African Americans, while children's health behaviors studies assess shifts in physical activity, sleep, and screen time, particularly during the pandemic, to inform public health initiatives.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: metabolomics, microbiome, machine learning, dietary impacts, cancer research, and personalized nutrition. 

Metabolomics is explored through studies on spontaneous preterm birth, identifying associations between vaginal metabolites and preterm birth risk, and predicting glycemic responses through machine learning. The microbiome research focuses on its diversity in relation to preterm birth, structural variations linked to health outcomes, and the gut-retina axis's influence on age-related macular degeneration. Machine learning is utilized to analyze metabolite levels and predict health outcomes, demonstrating its effectiveness in various studies. Dietary impacts are assessed through randomized trials examining different bread types and their glycemic responses, highlighting the significance of individual microbiome profiles. Cancer research emphasizes the role of the microbiome in cancer dynamics, with studies confirming cancer-specific microbial signatures and the development of SCRuB for decontaminating microbiome data to improve cancer predictions. Lastly, personalized nutrition is addressed through dietary interventions that consider individual variability in responses, showcasing the potential for tailored dietary recommendations based on microbiome data.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: dopamine D2 receptors (D2Rs), cholinergic interneurons (CINs), basal ganglia circuitry, motor control, cognitive processes, psychiatric disorders, and addiction.

Dopamine D2 receptors (D2Rs) are central to this research, particularly their role in modulating acetylcholine levels and CIN activity in the striatum, affecting behaviors related to reward and learning. The modulation of ACh by D2Rs influences behavioral responses, especially in inhibitory learning tasks. The research also delves into basal ganglia circuitry, highlighting the role of D2Rs in motor control and learning, with findings on striatopallidal pathways and dopamine release dynamics. Cognitive processes are examined through the lens of psychiatric disorders, particularly schizophrenia, emphasizing the importance of thalamic activity and parvalbumin interneurons in cognitive flexibility. The research addresses addiction by exploring D2R availability and its impact on motivated behavior and metabolic processes. Overall, the intricate balance of D2R signaling is a recurring theme, linking these diverse fields and shedding light on their implications for mental health and behavioral disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: transplantation immunology, cardiac allograft rejection, microRNAs as biomarkers, antibody-mediated rejection (AMR), B cell dynamics in transplantation, natural antibodies (Nabs), and intestinal homeostasis assessment.

Transplantation immunology is a central focus, examining the immune responses involved in organ transplant rejection. Cardiac allograft rejection is specifically addressed, with studies revealing the role of autoantibodies and the importance of timing in AMR related to graft dysfunction and outcomes. The exploration of microRNAs as non-invasive biomarkers for cardiac allograft rejection aims to improve detection methods beyond invasive biopsies. Research on AMR highlights the influence of both major and minor histocompatibility antigens, as well as the emerging significance of non-HLA antibodies. B cell dynamics are investigated, particularly their clonal expansion and roles in graft health and rejection mechanisms. The role of Nabs in innate immunity is explored, particularly their association with graft loss and the immune response in early infancy. Lastly, the development of an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for assessing intestinal homeostasis provides insights into non-invasive monitoring of inflammation in patients with ileostomies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Alzheimer's disease (AD), microglial function, cellular interactions in the aging brain, BIN1 protein and tau pathology, transcriptomic studies, metaflammasome, obesity, nuclear transport, and oxidative stress.

Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a central focus, particularly the molecular mechanisms and cellular interactions involved. Research on microglial function reveals distinct transcriptional programs linked to _-amyloid and tau pathologies. The study of cellular interactions in the aging brain employs single-nucleus RNA sequencing to create a cellular map, identifying diverse populations associated with AD. The BIN1 protein, an AD susceptibility gene, is investigated for its isoform expression in various brain cell types and its role in tau pathology. Transcriptomic studies address cell-type heterogeneity, enhancing understanding of gene expression dynamics in neurodegenerative diseases. The metaflammasome is explored in relation to obesity and AD, revealing its role in brain signaling and metabolic responses. Finally, research on nuclear transport examines the influence of disulfide bonds and oxidative stress on nuclear pore complex permeability, linking redox state to cellular processes in neurodegeneration.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: aptamer development, microfluidic technology, molecular computing, pain management, therapeutic advancements, and diagnostic algorithms. Aptamer development focuses on innovative methods for isolating high-affinity nucleic-acid-based receptors for small molecules and steroids, enhancing clinical applications. Microfluidic technology is employed in various contexts, including the rapid selection of aptamers and efficient cell capture and release techniques. Molecular computing is explored through the use of hybrid chiral molecules and antibody-directed molecular automata for analyzing cell surfaces and detecting DNA signals. Pain management research addresses interventions for low back pain, including radiofrequency ablation and thermal annular procedures, emphasizing evidence-based methodologies. Therapeutic advancements include the development of anti-idiotype aptamers for COVID-19 detection and new compounds for organophosphate toxicity reactivation. Lastly, diagnostic algorithms are examined for efficient assessment of lumbosacral pain, showcasing the integration of advanced techniques in clinical settings.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: calcium channels, cardiac health, ion channel regulation, genetic engineering, epigenome editing, and neurodevelopmental disorders. 

Calcium channels are a primary focus, particularly their regulation and inhibition, with studies on adrenergic modulation and the role of specific phosphorylation sites in cardiac calcium channels. Research on genetically-encoded voltage-dependent calcium channel inhibitors (GECCIs) explores new strategies for targeting high-voltage-activated calcium channels (HVACCs). In cardiac health, the impact of diet and genetic mutations on ion channel function is investigated, revealing mechanisms linking high-fat diets to arrhythmias and the effects of engineered deubiquitinases on dysfunctional channels. Ion channel regulation is further examined through targeted ubiquitination techniques and the role of G-proteins in calcium channel functionality. Genetic engineering is explored with novel strategies like multiplex epigenome editing for reactivating the MECP2 gene in Rett syndrome, demonstrating therapeutic potential. Lastly, the research on neurodevelopmental disorders emphasizes the application of epigenetic modifications to address genetic conditions, showcasing innovative approaches to treatment.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: retinal diseases, gene therapy, CRISPR editing, genetic mutations, metabolic reprogramming, imaging techniques, and personalized medicine. Retinal diseases are a primary focus, particularly inherited conditions like retinitis pigmentosa (RP) and Leber Congenital Amaurosis 8 (LCA8), with studies addressing their genetic and clinical characteristics. Gene therapy is explored through various animal models, emphasizing the challenges of translating preclinical findings to clinical applications. CRISPR editing is investigated as a potential therapeutic approach, particularly targeting the PHD2 gene to enhance photoreceptor survival. The study of genetic mutations, including CRB1 and BEST1, reveals significant phenotypic variability and novel variants linked to distinct retinal disorders. Metabolic reprogramming through AMPK modulation shows promise in preserving photoreceptor function. Imaging techniques, such as quantitative fundus autofluorescence and multimodal imaging, are utilized to diagnose and monitor disease progression. Lastly, personalized medicine approaches, including iPSC-derived therapies, are highlighted for their potential to address the diverse genetic landscape of retinal diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: DNA damage and repair, transcription regulation, biocatalysis, and metal ion biochemistry. 

DNA damage and repair research focuses on the mechanisms of insertions at double-strand breaks (DSBs) and their implications in cancer, highlighting pathways such as transcription-coupled mechanisms and the role of DksA in DSB repair. Transcription regulation studies involve the NusG transcription factor's role in enhancing gene expression, the impact of ribonucleoside-5'-diphosphates on RNA polymerase, and the structural basis of transcription arrest by the HK022 Nun protein. Biocatalysis research examines the role of divalent metal ions in enzyme activity, demonstrating that the coordination features of these ions are crucial for catalysis, particularly emphasizing the unique role of Mg2+ in biocatalysis. Lastly, metal ion biochemistry explores the influence of inorganic phosphate on transcription regulation, revealing that different physical states of phosphate can significantly affect RNA synthesis and cleavage mechanisms. Collectively, these areas underscore the complex interplay between transcription dynamics, DNA repair processes, and biochemical catalysis.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pediatric rapid response teams, nephrology, acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD), early-onset sepsis (EOS), risk assessment in neonatology, and management strategies in neonatal care.

Pediatric rapid response teams focus on improving patient outcomes in critical situations. This researcher implemented a formal debriefing program following rapid response activations to enhance learning and improvement processes. In nephrology, the research investigates the consequences of preterm birth on nephron endowment, linking reduced nephron numbers to increased risks of AKI and CKD. The development of mouse models has been pivotal in demonstrating how low nephron counts lead to maladaptive renal changes and heightened susceptibility to injury from gentamicin. In the realm of early-onset sepsis, the researcher emphasizes the need for better risk assessment tools, advocating for alternatives like the Bayesian sepsis calculator to minimize unnecessary interventions in low-risk newborns, thereby addressing the challenges of overtreatment and improving neonatal care strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neocortical activity, neuronal avalanches, circadian rhythms, olfactory bulb, spontaneous activity, visual habituation, holographic imaging, neuronal ensembles, and visual stimuli encoding.

Neocortical activity research focuses on how the cortex exhibits stimulus- and scale-invariance, with findings indicating that it operates near a critical state characterized by power law distributions of neuronal avalanches. The study of neuronal avalanches explores their consistency across stimuli and the adaptability of microcircuits in the visual cortex. The investigation of circadian rhythms examines the role of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide (VIP) in the olfactory bulb, revealing its significance in maintaining these rhythms and odor detection performance. Research on spontaneous activity in the cortex during visual habituation demonstrates its correlation with habituation levels and its role in sensory information processing. The development of a novel holographic imaging method allows for simultaneous multi-plane calcium imaging, enhancing understanding of neural circuits. Lastly, the study of neuronal ensembles investigates how groups of neurons encode visual stimuli through temporal activity patterns, suggesting that intrinsic dynamics of these ensembles are crucial for processing visual information.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: radon exposure, stroke, cadmium exposure, metabolic syndrome, magnesium intake, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, long-chain n-3 fatty acids, cognitive performance, B vitamins, diabetes mellitus, zinc and cognitive function, selenium and thyroid cancer, dietary fats and telomere length, maternal e-cigarette exposure, and aluminum exposure.

Radon exposure research investigates its relationship with stroke, cerebrovascular disease, and dementia, revealing complex interactions influenced by smoking and inconsistent associations across populations. Cadmium exposure is linked to metabolic syndrome, particularly in Asian demographics, while magnesium intake shows potential protective effects against non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The impact of long-chain n-3 fatty acids, mercury, and selenium on cognitive performance in infants is also explored. B vitamins are studied for their role in metabolic syndrome incidence, diabetes, and cardiovascular disease prevention. Additionally, zinc's association with cognitive function and selenium's link to thyroid cancer are examined. The research further analyzes dietary fats' effects on telomere length and the implications of maternal e-cigarette exposure on offspring development, alongside the influence of aluminum exposure on motor performance.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: SARS-CoV-2 structural proteins, calcium homeostasis, phosphatidylinositol-phosphate biosynthesis, crystal structure of ligands, calcium-sensing receptor activation, defective thyroglobulin, autoimmune thyroiditis, integral membrane enzymes, ivabradine and HCN4 channels, thyroglobulin trafficking, ankyrin-1 complex, ryanodine receptor, cepharanthine in autoimmune models, GABAB receptor structure, STRA6 receptor, CysZ and sulfate uptake. 

The research investigates how SARS-CoV-2 structural proteins disrupt calcium homeostasis and interorganelle contact, suggesting therapeutic targets. It also characterizes phosphatidylinositol-phosphate biosynthesis in mycobacteria, focusing on the enzyme PIPS. The crystal structure of the LGR ligand from C. elegans reveals evolutionary links to human hormones, while the calcium-sensing receptor study elucidates its activation mechanism. Research on defective thyroglobulin highlights genetic impacts on thyroid disease, and a novel mouse model of autoimmune thyroiditis allows for investigation of thyroglobulin variants. Studies on integral membrane enzymes explore their catalytic adaptations. Additionally, ivabradine's binding to HCN4 channels is detailed, along with insights into thyroglobulin trafficking and the ankyrin-1 complex. Structural studies of the ryanodine receptor and GABAB receptor provide critical information on their functions, while cepharanthine's effects in autoimmune models and the mechanisms of sulfate uptake by CysZ are also explored.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: early adversity, cognitive control, emotional regulation, amygdala-prefrontal circuitry, developmental psychology, neuroscience, mental health, and parenting. Early adversity research focuses on its multifaceted impacts on development, revealing how interpersonal and socioeconomic adversities uniquely affect brain volume, sensory processing, and psychological outcomes. Cognitive control studies investigate how early caregiving instability influences children's cognitive flexibility and inhibitory control, highlighting the complex effects of caregiving environments. Emotional regulation is examined through the lens of amygdala-prefrontal circuitry, where interventions improve connectivity and decrease anxiety in children exposed to adversity. Developmental psychology and neuroscience intersect in exploring cortical thickness, memory retrieval, and neural responses to narratives, emphasizing the brain-body connection in stress regulation. Mental health research delves into the effects of early life stress on amygdala development and emotional regulation, while parenting studies reveal the significant role of caregiver relationships in shaping emotional and behavioral outcomes in children. Overall, these studies underscore the intricate interplay between early experiences, neurodevelopment, and mental health trajectories.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Electromechanical Wave Imaging (EWI), cardiac electrophysiology, arrhythmias, transthoracic impedance (TTI), ventricular tachycardia, viral infections and arrhythmias, cardiac sympathetic denervation, mitochondrial dysfunction, dietary impacts on arrhythmias, digital health in arrhythmia management, cardiac transplantation, and complications of atrial fibrillation ablation.
