This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: myelination, deep learning, genetics, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), neurofibromatosis, cannabis use, postpartum psychosis, zinc transporters, cognitive function, fear generalization, neurodevelopmental disorders, Alzheimer's disease, social behavior, schizophrenia, cerebellar function, immune activation, SARS-CoV-2, and neuroinflammation.

Myelination studies focus on its role in cortical networks and its effects on gamma oscillations and epilepsy. The GenNet framework enhances deep learning applications in genetics, identifying gene-trait relationships. Research on ASD highlights the therapeutic potential of MEK inhibition in RASopathies. Neurofibromatosis investigations reveal links between cortical excitability and cognitive disabilities. Cannabis use studies examine its correlation with psychotic experiences in offspring. Postpartum psychosis research explores treatment efficacy and immune system involvement. Zinc transporter studies investigate the impact of ZIP7 on cell proliferation. Cognitive function research assesses surgical impacts, while fear generalization studies link glucocorticoids to increased engram populations. Neurodevelopmental disorder research includes UBE3A isoforms and netrin-G2 mutations. Alzheimer's studies connect genetic variants to neuroinflammation. Social behavior research assesses oxytocin's effects on aggression. Schizophrenia studies implicate oligodendrocyte dysfunction. Cerebellar function research evaluates synaptic transmission's role in cognition. Immune activation studies link T cells to antidepressant response. Lastly, SARS-CoV-2 research clarifies neurological complications related to immune responses rather than viral replication.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: photodynamic therapy (PDT), biocompatibility of photosensitizers, scattering properties of biological cells, gastric cancer, oral health and pregnancy outcomes, microbial analysis in pregnancy, Fusobacterium nucleatum and colorectal cancer, and tumor microenvironment interactions.

Photodynamic therapy (PDT) advancements focus on enhancing the biocompatibility of porphyrins through carbon dots, improving solubility and reducing toxicity. The study of scattering properties investigates how Laguerre-Gaussian beams interact with complex-shaped biological cells, providing insights into light interactions with cells. Research on gastric cancer addresses diagnostic challenges post-Helicobacter pylori eradication, identifying risk factors like gastric atrophy. The oral health studies link periodontal disease to adverse pregnancy outcomes and explore Fusobacterium nucleatum's role in systemic diseases and cancer. Additionally, microbial analysis in pregnancy highlights bacterial prevalence in stillbirths and the effectiveness of antiseptic strategies in cesarean deliveries. Fusobacterium nucleatum is further examined for its pathogenic mechanisms in colorectal cancer, with implications for diagnostics and treatment strategies, while the tumor microenvironment's impact on non-small cell lung cancer therapies is also explored.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: visual processing, primate neuroscience, optogenetics, decision-making, motion perception, and neural circuits.

Visual processing research focuses on understanding object recognition mechanisms in primates, particularly through studies on the interactions between the ventrolateral prefrontal cortex and visual area V4. This includes investigating how neurons in V4 respond to occluded stimuli and maintain selectivity for partially occluded shapes. Primate neuroscience encompasses the broader exploration of neural mechanisms underlying visual form processing, including the characterization of V1 neurons projecting to V2.

Optogenetics research investigates the application of optogenetic techniques in primate cerebellar studies, revealing insights into Purkinje cell functions and immune responses to gene delivery. Decision-making studies examine the lateral intraparietal area's role in decision biases through neural inactivation, while also introducing novel optogenetic methods for fast neural inactivation in the visual cortex.

Motion perception research delves into the dynamics of direction discrimination and decision confidence in the macaque area MT, highlighting the effects of optogenetic suppression and the spatial-temporal limits of pattern motion sensitivity in MT neurons, contributing to the understanding of hierarchical processing in motion perception.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: breast cancer, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), T cell dynamics, colloidal nanoparticles (CNPs), inflammasomes, antiviral research, and structural biology.

Breast cancer research focuses on silibinin's cytotoxic effects on MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 cells via YAP/TAZ pathway inhibition, inducing mitochondrial fission and enhancing mitophagy. Graft-versus-host disease studies highlight Ibrutinib's role in preventing cGVHD in mice by inhibiting BTK and ITK, improving survival and reducing symptoms. T cell dynamics research investigates tissue resident memory T cells in transplantation, T cell responses to SARS-CoV-2, and the impact of T-bet on GVHD pathogenesis. Colloidal nanoparticles research examines physicochemical changes during lamb soup stewing, revealing structural transformations and stability enhancements. Inflammasome studies explore the assembly and regulation of NLRP3 and caspase-1, linking them to various diseases. Antiviral research identifies an isoxazole-3-carboxamide analog as a potent inhibitor of Enterovirus-D68 and Coxsackievirus B5, while structural biology investigates the mechanisms of NLRP3 inflammasome assembly and evaluates algal viruses for UV treatment validation.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: mitochondrial function, fragile X syndrome (FXS), autism spectrum disorder (ASD), mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP), anesthesiology, propofol-induced cardiotoxicity, and translational science.

Mitochondrial function is a central theme, particularly its implications in FXS and ASD, where mitochondrial dysfunction is linked to neurodevelopmental outcomes. In FXS mice, altered brown adipose tissue mitochondrial function and CoQ deficiency were noted, impacting thermogenic respiration and synaptogenesis. The mPTP's role in diseases like myocardial ischemia and Alzheimer's is also investigated, focusing on voltage sensing and CoQ modulation. Anesthesiology is highlighted for its translational science potential, especially in improving patient care during the COVID-19 pandemic. Research on propofol-induced cardiotoxicity reveals its effects on pediatric patients, emphasizing mitochondrial impairment and dysrhythmias in newborn mice. The PANDA symposium showcases ongoing research into anesthetic neurotoxicity, aiming to clarify mechanisms and protective strategies. Overall, this research underscores the intricate relationships between mitochondrial function, neurodevelopment, and anesthetic safety in vulnerable populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: brain-machine interfaces (BMIs), motor control, neural dynamics, decision-making processes, and spiking neural networks.

Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) are a central focus, particularly the development of a self-motion BMI that allows for near-native control performance in monkeys cycling a pedal, revealing insights into neural activity covariance structures. Motor control research emphasizes flexible neural control of motor units (MUs) during voluntary movement, challenging traditional hierarchical views and demonstrating the cortex's role in dynamically adjusting MU activity. Neural dynamics is explored through the prediction of future activity in the motor cortex, enhancing BMI performance by incorporating these dynamics into models. Decision-making processes are examined through motor cortex activity, which reflects complex internal states during learned movements and decision-making scenarios. Lastly, the study of spiking neural networks introduces methods for training these networks, emphasizing the relationship between discrete neuronal spikes and lower-dimensional population factors, contributing to a deeper understanding of neural computation and dynamics.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: epilepsy, genetic models, neurodevelopmental disorders, RNA binding proteins, neuroinflammation, and brain development.

Epilepsy research focuses on understanding the mechanisms underlying various forms of the disorder through mouse models, including the role of genetic mutations like KCNT1 and DNM1, and their effects on neuronal excitability and synaptic transmission. Genetic models are employed to explore developmental and epileptic encephalopathy (DEE), revealing insights into altered synaptic activity and potential therapeutic targets. Neurodevelopmental disorders are investigated through studies on HNRNPU and IQSEC2 mutations, highlighting their impact on cognitive function and synaptic regulation. RNA binding proteins are examined using the Protein-RNA Association Strength (PRAS) method, which enhances the identification of mRNA targets and post-transcriptional regulation. Neuroinflammation and its connection to Glut1 deficiency syndrome emphasize the importance of Glut1 in brain health. Lastly, brain development research explores the effects of Id2 on neural stem cells, linking its dysregulation to microcephaly and seizures, thus contributing to the understanding of neurological disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: glioblastoma, microRNA regulation, tumor microenvironment, atherosclerosis, diabetes, proteomics, CRISPR-Cas9, cancer stemness, ferroptosis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), melatonin, airway inflammation, imaging techniques, dietary influences, nursing interventions, and metabolic disorders.

The research on glioblastoma focuses on the PRR11-DHODH axis, which promotes resistance to temozolomide and ferroptosis, suggesting potential combined therapy strategies. In the area of microRNA regulation, studies reveal that microRNA-381-5p enhances resistance to Spiroplasma eriocheiris infection in crabs. The investigation of the tumor microenvironment includes developing a dual-catalysis carbon-based nanoenzyme for improved photodynamic therapy. Research on atherosclerosis highlights how low shear stress induces neutrophil extracellular traps through Piezo1. Diabetes research includes identifying a novel STAT3 variant linked to infantile-onset diabetes and autoimmunity. Proteomic analysis identifies APOA2 as a biomarker for intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy. CRISPR-Cas9 protocols facilitate the identification of ferroptosis regulators, while studies on cancer stemness explore the inhibition of hepatocellular carcinoma via the Wnt/_-catenin pathway. Other areas include the effects of melatonin on neuronal protection, mechanisms of COPD improvement through aerobic training, and the impacts of diet on puberty and metabolic disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: refeeding syndrome (RFS), IgA nephropathy, community-acquired Clostridioides difficile infection (CA-CDI), COVID-19 and gastrointestinal health, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage kidney disease (ESKD), inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), esophageal adenocarcinoma, gut microbiome dynamics, and antimicrobial resistance.

Refeeding syndrome research focuses on its definitions and associations with mortality in ICU patients. IgA nephropathy studies reveal higher incidence rates in specific demographics. Research on CA-CDI identifies antibiotics as risk factors. COVID-19 studies explore persistent gastrointestinal and mental health symptoms linked to gut microbiome alterations. PPI research examines trends, prescribing habits, and risks associated with long-term use, including infection links. CKD and ESKD studies highlight global care variability. IBD research investigates predictors of flare time, treatment efficacy, and complications from infections. Esophageal adenocarcinoma studies assess microbiome alterations' impact on disease progression. Gut microbiome dynamics research in critical care settings analyzes infection risks, dietary influences, and antimicrobial resistance. Overall, this research encompasses a wide range of health issues related to gastrointestinal health and systemic infections.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: stress and feeding behaviors, metabolic regulation, leptin signaling, maternal nutrition, obesity, neuronal circuits, anorexia nervosa, and scientific publishing in nutritional science.

Research on stress and feeding behaviors reveals that stress can variably alter eating patterns, with significant influences from sex, estrous cyclicity, and diet palatability. The metabolic regulation aspect focuses on leptin signaling in the hypothalamic arcuate nucleus, where distinct neuronal populations, including POMC neurons, play critical roles in energy balance and the action of anti-obesity drugs. Maternal nutrition is highlighted as a key factor influencing offspring obesity risk, with early-life exposures affecting hypothalamic circuits and feeding behaviors. The obesity research emphasizes energy homeostasis disorders and the impact of high-fat diets on leptin signaling. In the context of anorexia nervosa, the need for improved preclinical models is discussed, alongside the complexity of POMC neurons in appetite regulation. Lastly, the critique of misleading statements in nutritional science underscores the importance of accuracy and rigorous peer review in scientific publishing to ensure reliable health information.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Zika virus (ZIKV) and dengue virus (DENV) infections, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), life sciences technologies, spatial transcriptomics (SRT), and Alzheimer's disease (AD). 

The investigation into ZIKV and DENV focuses on their transcriptional and translational dynamics in human neuronal progenitor cells, revealing distinct responses in RNA translation and stress mechanisms. In ALS research, the emphasis is on retromer dysfunction and the role of astrocytes in motor neuron degeneration, utilizing advanced in vitro models and spatial transcriptomics to explore gene expression and glial dynamics. The development of PySeq2500 represents a significant advancement in life sciences, enabling automated imaging for complex experiments. The review of SRT highlights its potential in cancer research, particularly in understanding tumor heterogeneity. Finally, the study of late-onset Alzheimer's disease examines genetic and epigenomic factors, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive understanding of biological pathways to enhance drug discovery and personalized care approaches.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: ciliated protists, genomic stability, transposons, genome dynamics, DNA methylation, NT-seq, protein architecture, nucleosome mapping, and RNA-mediated mechanisms. Research on ciliated protists focuses on the unique genomic features of these organisms, particularly the presence of "junk" DNA insertions derived from transposons, which impact gene expression and genomic stability. The study of genome dynamics investigates the complex rearrangements in ciliated genomes, with Oxytricha trifallax exhibiting significant complexity and evolutionary implications. DNA methylation research, particularly through the NT-seq method, explores various methylation types in prokaryotes, providing a comprehensive profiling approach. The investigation of protein architecture, specifically TIM barrel proteins, highlights their evolutionary role in metabolism. Nucleosome mapping studies reveal how DNA sequence preferences influence nucleosome positioning, while research on RNA-mediated mechanisms uncovers their regulatory roles in genetic innovation and chromosome dynamics, further emphasizing the intricate relationship between genomic architecture and evolutionary processes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: virtual reality (VR), human behavioral neuroscience, sensorimotor learning, decision-making processes, motor control, motor adaptation, and cognitive load.

Virtual reality (VR) is explored through the development of Ouvrai, an open-source platform that enhances remote VR studies in human behavioral neuroscience, utilizing high-resolution kinematic data and immersive 3D graphics. Human behavioral neuroscience focuses on sensorimotor learning, examining how motor responses and memories adapt, including the optimization of corrective responses and the rigidity of categorical encoding. Decision-making processes are investigated across various contexts, revealing insights into perceptual decision-making, cognitive bottlenecks, and the influence of confidence on multi-stage decisions. Motor control studies delve into how individuals learn reaching strategies and the effects of contextual cues on motor memory. Motor adaptation research includes the impact of bias and noise on target selection, the role of reinforcement learning, and age-related changes in motor adaptation. Lastly, cognitive load is addressed in relation to weight prediction and the efficiency of decision-making under uncertainty, highlighting the interplay between memory formation and decay in optimizing performance.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: genetic disorders, hearing impairment, neurodevelopmental disorders, structural variants, genetic variants, diagnostic methodologies, and population genetics. 

Genetic disorders are a primary focus, with investigations into various genetic variants linked to conditions such as Cohen syndrome, atypical Gaucher disease, and Marfan syndrome. Hearing impairment is extensively studied, particularly through the identification of novel genetic variants associated with both syndromic and non-syndromic forms of hearing loss. Neurodevelopmental disorders are explored through the use of optical genome mapping to detect structural variants and pathogenic mutations in relevant genes. The research also delves into the significance of specific genetic variants, such as those in BCL11A and OPHN1, in relation to neurodevelopmental conditions. Diagnostic methodologies are advanced through targeted resequencing and microdroplet PCR, enhancing genetic diagnosis capabilities. Additionally, population genetics is addressed by highlighting genetic disparities in hearing impairment across different populations, emphasizing the importance of diverse genetic studies in understanding these conditions.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: genetic engineering, microbial biotechnology, enzyme engineering, biocatalysis, hydrometallurgy, and bioenergy. 

Genetic engineering focuses on modifying Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans (A. ferrooxidans) to enhance metal recovery and biochemical production, including the development of genetic tools for gene expression control. Microbial biotechnology emphasizes the role of A. ferrooxidans in bioprocessing and microbial corrosion, utilizing novel sulfur dispersion techniques and reactor configurations for electrofuels production. Enzyme engineering involves creating cofactor-independent oxidoreductases and enhancing enzyme activity through microenvironment engineering and modular designs. Biocatalysis explores kinetic modeling of formolase enzymes and the impact of substrate channelling on reaction efficiency. Hydrometallurgy investigates innovative methods for copper extraction using chromium(II) chloride, providing a rapid and efficient alternative to traditional methods. Lastly, bioenergy research examines the potential of non-photosynthetic chemolithoautotrophic bacteria in producing biochemicals from CO2 and the integration of microbiology with mining operations to advance biofuel production.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs), immune-mediated disorders, human microbiome, NF-_B signaling, cancer genetics, genetic analysis, and species identification.

Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) are studied for their regulatory roles in immune-mediated disorders, with genome-wide association studies revealing SNPs that impact their function and contribute to diseases like celiac disease and multiple sclerosis. The human microbiome's influence on health, particularly through microbial metabolites and the gut-immune axis, is another area of focus. NF-_B signaling is explored in relation to immune responses, cancer, and autoimmune diseases, with specific attention on subunits like RelA and c-Rel, tumor-suppressor genes like NKIRAS1, and therapeutic implications of HIF-1_ and PDK1. The researcher also investigates genetic and environmental factors in cancer susceptibility, particularly in Northeast India, emphasizing the role of DNA repair gene variants and tobacco exposure. Additionally, genetic analysis techniques, including DNA barcoding, are applied for species identification across various biological groups, enhancing understanding of biodiversity and genetic diversity in different contexts.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: genetics, intellectual disability, retinitis pigmentosa, dermatology, digital biobanks, sleep disorders, polydactyly, hearing impairment, essential tremor, orofaciodigital syndrome, branchio-otic syndrome, genetic epilepsy, atypical Gaucher disease, Marfan syndrome, Wolfram syndrome, AlzheimerÕs disease, and rare variant analysis.

Genetics is a central theme, with studies identifying variants linked to various conditions like intellectual disability and retinitis pigmentosa through genome-wide genotyping and exome sequencing. Research in dermatology focuses on utilizing digital biobanks to enhance understanding of skin diseases. The exploration of sleep disorders investigates the prevalence of sleepwalking and paralysis in families with genetic epilepsy. Polydactyly studies highlight genetic factors like EFCAB7 and FAM92A in limb development. Hearing impairment research identifies multiple genetic variants across diverse populations and conditions, including essential tremor and Marfan syndrome. The researcher also investigates rare variants associated with AlzheimerÕs disease and develops methods for analyzing genetic data, emphasizing the importance of quality control in genetic studies. Overall, the research underscores the genetic basis of various disorders and the potential for personalized medicine.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: osteoporosis, primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT), hypoparathyroidism, vitamin D, and metabolic bone diseases. Osteoporosis research focuses on the prevalence and treatment variations across Eurasian countries, the efficacy of anabolic agents like abaloparatide, and the need for improved fracture management, particularly in men. In PHPT, the researcher examines its clinical phenotypes, management strategies, and the dual effects of parathyroid hormone on bone. Hypoparathyroidism studies highlight the long-term effects of recombinant human PTH(1-84) and the challenges in male osteoporosis diagnosis and treatment. Vitamin D research investigates its role in COVID-19, insufficiency in specific populations, and its broader health implications beyond bone health. Lastly, the Santa Fe Bone Symposium series contributes to advancing knowledge in osteoporosis and metabolic bone diseases by discussing various treatment strategies, imaging advancements, and emerging guidelines. Overall, the research underscores the complexity of these conditions and the importance of ongoing investigation into their management and treatment.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: lung disease, autoimmune conditions, biomarkers, interstitial lung disease (ILD), systemic sclerosis (SSc), pulmonary hypertension (PH), healthcare resource utilization (HRU), and thrombotic complications.

Lung disease research focuses on understanding various forms of lung pathology, particularly interstitial lung disease (ILD) and its progression. The researcher investigates biomarkers like absolute monocyte count and D-Dimer levels to predict lung function decline and associated complications. Autoimmune conditions are explored in relation to lung diseases, with studies examining systemic sclerosis (SSc) and its impact on pulmonary health, including the role of pulmonary hypertension (PH) and valvular dysfunction. The implications of healthcare resource utilization (HRU) are analyzed, revealing a correlation between forced vital capacity (FVC) decline and increased hospitalizations in chronic fibrosing ILD patients. Additionally, the researcher addresses thrombotic complications in autoimmune diseases, emphasizing the need for multidisciplinary management approaches. Overall, the research highlights the interplay between autoimmune features and lung disease, aiming to improve clinical assessments and patient outcomes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: left ventricular assist devices (LVADs), prostate cancer, DNA damage response (DDR), signaling pathways in cancer treatment, and surgical management of complications.

Left ventricular assist devices (LVADs) are critical in treating advanced heart failure but pose risks such as bleeding, infection, and device malfunction. The researcher emphasizes the importance of proper LVAD driveline placement to prevent severe complications like bowel obstruction and colonic perforation. In prostate cancer research, the focus is on RAD9's role in metastasis and tumorigenicity, particularly its regulation of genes like FOXP1 and NDRG1, influencing cell proliferation and migration. The study also highlights RAD9's involvement in DNA repair mechanisms, including its essential role in the DNA damage response, particularly in the context of male meiosis. Additionally, the researcher investigates the MEK5/ERK5 signaling pathway's impact on enhancing sensitivity to DNA-damaging agents, while also addressing the limitations of same-hospital readmission rates in assessing post-operative infections. Lastly, the potential of PARP inhibition in improving treatment outcomes for specific lung cancer types is explored, indicating a promising direction for therapeutic strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: critical care medicine, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), neurological recovery, cardiac arrest, cognitive assessment, and patient outcomes. 

In critical care medicine, the researcher emphasizes the need for targeted post-ICU treatment for cardiac arrest survivors, proposing frameworks to address their recovery needs. The exploration of cognitive assessments in critical care highlights methodological considerations for evaluating patients. PTSD research focuses on the prevalence and impact of symptoms in patients after acute cardiac events, revealing how these symptoms can hinder engagement in secondary prevention behaviors. Neurological recovery studies investigate factors influencing recovery outcomes post-cardiac arrest, including the role of quantitative EEG in predicting consciousness recovery. The research on cardiac arrest encompasses understanding the long-term risks and outcomes associated with various etiologies, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage and intracerebral hemorrhage. Lastly, patient outcomes research examines how psychological distress, gender disparities, and treatment center practices affect recovery perceptions and health behaviors in cardiac arrest survivors.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs), neurodegenerative diseases, ferroptosis, ischemic stroke, digital biomarkers, Parkinson's disease, lipid metabolism, coronary heart disease, immune function, acupuncture, tic disorders, inflammation, omega-3 fatty acids, cardiovascular diseases, atherosclerosis, smooth muscle cells, macrophage biology, IL-6, TNF-_, type 2 diabetes, lipoprotein(a), inflammation, monocytes, high-density lipoprotein (HDL), omics technologies, stroke, drug combination therapy, DNA damage response (DDR), machine learning, and gene expression.

The researcher investigates ASOs for treating oligodendrocyte dysfunction in neurodegenerative diseases, focusing on glial-targeted therapies. They explore the role of Nrf2 in mitigating ferroptosis during ischemic stroke. The integration of digital biomarkers enhances predictions for Parkinson's disease using deep learning. Lipid metabolism and immune function are examined through lysosomal acid lipase's role in coronary heart disease. Acupuncture techniques for tic disorders are investigated alongside the anti-inflammatory potential of omega-3 fatty acids. Research on atherosclerosis includes characterizing smooth muscle cell behaviors and macrophage biology, with insights into inflammatory cytokines' effects on endothelial dysfunction in type 2 diabetes. The relationship between lipoprotein(a) and inflammation is explored, alongside the therapeutic potential of trained monocytes and HDL. The researcher also emphasizes omics technologies for understanding atherosclerotic plaques and develops machine learning methods for drug combination predictions, focusing on gene expression differences in inflammatory responses.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neuroscience technology, neuronal activity, imaging techniques, circuit dynamics, therapeutic strategies, cellular classification, synaptic function, quantum sensing, neuroethics, and cnidarian neuroscience.

Neuroscience technology focuses on innovations like TraSE-IN for tracking calcium signals and high-density microelectrode arrays for cellular-resolution studies. Neuronal activity research emphasizes the role of neuronal ensembles in visual encoding and the dynamics of action potentials. Imaging techniques include aberration-free holographic microscopy and two-photon calcium imaging for studying neural circuits. Circuit dynamics explore the stability and flexibility of neuronal ensembles, particularly in relation to memory and perception.

Therapeutic strategies involve light-based treatments for cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Cellular classification proposes a standardized nomenclature based on transcriptomics. Synaptic function investigates dendritic spine properties and their implications for plasticity. Quantum sensing research examines the modulation of nitrogen vacancy centers in nanodiamonds for biological applications. Neuroethics addresses privacy concerns in neurodata. Lastly, cnidarian neuroscience studies Hydra vulgaris to uncover fundamental neural principles and behaviors, advocating for further exploration of simple nervous systems.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: regulatory T (Treg) cells, liver fibrosis, insulin resistance, non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), gut microbiota, lung regeneration, colitis, cancer immunotherapy, engineered probiotics, synthetic biology, and bacterial delivery systems. 

Research on regulatory T (Treg) cells explores their dual role in immune regulation and tissue repair, particularly in liver fibrosis and NASH, where Treg-derived amphiregulin promotes pro-fibrotic pathways. The impact of dietary tryptophan deficiency on gut microbiota and Treg composition is also examined, revealing shifts in Treg subtypes. In lung regeneration, Treg cells support epithelial recovery post-viral infection through interactions with mesenchymal cells. The role of Treg cells in colitis involves modulating macrophage responses to reduce inflammation. In cancer, Treg cells can promote tumor progression via amphiregulin. 

Innovative cancer therapies focus on engineered probiotics and bacteria, including probiotic-guided CAR-T cells for targeted tumor lysis, bacteria that recruit immune cells to tumors, and systems for local delivery of checkpoint inhibitors. These studies highlight synthetic biology's potential in improving cancer immunotherapy through effective bacterial delivery systems and enhancing immune responses.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cerebrovascular anatomy, vascular pathologies, hemorrhagic transformation (HT), stroke management, brain arteriovenous malformations (AVMs), predictors of stroke outcomes, and antiplatelet therapy. 

Cerebrovascular anatomy focuses on the structural and functional characteristics of cerebral arteries and their susceptibility to vascular diseases, particularly in relation to clinical syndromes affecting the brain. The study of vascular pathologies examines diseases impacting intracranial vessels and their implications. Hemorrhagic transformation (HT) is a significant area, investigating predictors of HT in stroke patients, especially those not treated with reperfusion therapies, and developing scoring systems like PROpHET. Stroke management encompasses evaluating congruency between clinical presentations and neuroimaging findings, as well as the prognostic significance of antiphospholipid antibodies in recurrent thrombotic events. Research on brain arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) addresses their grading and associated risks of stroke and mortality. Lastly, the role of antiplatelet therapy, particularly vorapaxar, is assessed in the context of managing stroke patients, emphasizing the need for tailored treatment approaches.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: structural parasitology, cryo-electron microscopy (cryoEM), gene editing, cryo-electron tomography (cryoET), structural proteomics, protein complexes, malaria biology, transport mechanisms, and community-building in parasitology. 

Structural parasitology focuses on understanding the biology of Plasmodium falciparum through advanced imaging techniques. Cryo-electron microscopy (cryoEM) is utilized for atomic resolution structure determination, enabling the exploration of the P. falciparum proteome and macromolecular complexes. Gene editing complements this by allowing targeted investigations of specific proteins. Cryo-electron tomography (cryoET) provides insights into the ultrastructures within the cellular context, enhancing knowledge of malaria pathogenesis. The development of a bottom-up structural proteomics approach using cryoEM allows for the reconstruction of near-atomic-resolution maps of protein complexes directly from cells, overcoming limitations of traditional methods. The research also investigates transport mechanisms during parasite invasion, emphasizing the role of the vacuolar compartment and the Plasmodium Translocon of EXported proteins (PTEX). Lastly, the researcher contributes to community-building in parasitology through initiatives like the Young Investigators in Parasitology (YIPs) meeting, which supports new principal investigators in developing their research careers.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: spinal muscular atrophy (SMA), amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), neuromuscular junction (NMJ) integrity, survival motor neuron (SMN) protein, U7 small nuclear ribonucleoprotein (snRNP), synaptic connectivity, serotonergic dysfunction, motor neuron pathophysiology, and imaging techniques in neurobiology.

Research on spinal muscular atrophy (SMA) emphasizes the role of serotonergic dysfunction in impairing locomotor coordination and highlights the importance of early intervention to prevent motor axon degeneration. The survival motor neuron (SMN) protein is crucial for NMJ integrity and U7 snRNP biogenesis, with dysfunction in these areas contributing to neuromuscular pathology. In ALS, the study of MuSK stimulation suggests potential therapeutic strategies for preserving neuromuscular synapses. Additionally, the research explores synaptic connectivity and the implications of classical complement pathways in synaptic elimination. Imaging techniques, specifically confocal and STED microscopy, are employed to analyze premotor synapses in the spinal cord, providing insights into neurodegenerative disease mechanisms. Overall, the research highlights complex interactions among molecular, cellular, and synaptic factors in motor neuron diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: intracellular phase separation, short cationic peptide tags, charge-patterned disordered peptides, complex coacervation, protein chemistry, bioconjugation techniques, protein delivery, and biomolecular patterning. 

Intracellular phase separation is a key focus, investigating how short cationic peptide tags facilitate this process in globular proteins, enhancing cellular organization. The use of charge-patterned disordered peptides is explored to tune phase separation in E. coli, revealing the influence of electrostatic interactions on biomolecular condensates. The research on complex coacervation emphasizes the role of protein charge patterning and supercharging, demonstrating how these factors affect phase behavior and protein encapsulation. In protein chemistry, the self-assembly of disordered polypeptides with synthetic polyelectrolytes is examined for biocompatibility and phase behavior. Bioconjugation techniques are highlighted through various methods, including enhancing intracellular delivery of protein therapeutics, fabricating 3D antibody arrays, and developing mild conjugation methods. Additionally, biomolecular patterning and the use of multivalent viral capsids for imaging are explored, showcasing innovative approaches in protein delivery and detection.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pancreas transplantation, glycemic control, kidney transplantation, ischemia-reperfusion injury, chronic histological changes, donor organ availability, and transplant outcomes.

Pancreas transplantation research focuses on establishing programs to enhance organ availability and reduce waitlist times, emphasizing the long-distance importation of pancreata to improve patient access and outcomes. Glycemic control studies compare pancreas transplantation to newer insulin delivery therapies, highlighting the biological advantages of pancreas transplants in managing blood glucose levels. 

In kidney transplantation, the researcher investigates the effects of chronic histological changes on allograft survival, revealing that kidneys with suboptimal histology have inferior outcomes and higher rejection rates. The impact of ischemia-reperfusion injury on allograft rejection is also examined, suggesting that severe injury and low dendritic cell density are strong predictors of rejection. 

Additional studies address disparities in access to transplantation, the influence of donor kidney characteristics on outcomes, and novel therapies for managing ischemia-reperfusion injury, ultimately aiming to optimize transplant practices and improve patient care.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: colorectal cancer, breast cancer, genetic interrogation, yeast adaptation, prokaryotic expression profiling, CRISPR technology, neuroinflammation, RNA processing, machine learning, and antibiotic resistance.

In colorectal cancer, the researcher focuses on mechanisms of metastasis and RNA processing, identifying the ITPR3/calcium/RELB axis as critical for liver colonization. In breast cancer, TARBP2's role in mRNA destabilization linked to metastasis is explored. Genetic interrogation is advanced through an inducible CRISPR interference library in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, facilitating the study of adenine and arginine biosynthesis. Yeast adaptation research highlights transcriptional reprogramming under lethal ethanol stress. Prokaryotic expression profiling via PETRI-seq reveals bacterial transcriptomic diversity. The CALM technique enhances CRISPR library generation for antibiotic resistance studies, while intracellular acidification is identified as a key factor in thymineless death in E. coli. Additionally, the researcher employs machine learning to model mRNA stability during zebrafish development and investigates neuroinflammation through microglial gene expression in ALS models.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: bladder cancer, prostate cancer, genetically engineered mouse models (GEMMs), precision medicine, master regulator (MR) proteins, NKX3.1 gene, metformin, cancer signaling pathways, cancer prevention science, and cancer disparities.

Research on bladder cancer focuses on developing GEMMs to understand disease mechanisms and identify prognostic signatures linked to progression. In prostate cancer, GEMMs reveal critical insights into MYC/RAS co-activation and immune profiling during tumor progression. The precision medicine framework, OncoLoop, predicts drug sensitivity using drug perturbation profiles and has shown efficacy in advanced prostate cancer cases. The identification of MR proteins and their modules highlights the connection between tumor genetics and transcriptional identity. The NKX3.1 gene's role in prostate cancer is explored, particularly its interaction with metformin and its influence on mitochondrial function and differentiation. Additionally, the research addresses cancer signaling pathways, emphasizing the importance of canonical Wnt signaling and the ERK/AKT pathways in tumor growth. Lastly, the researcher contributes to cancer prevention science by advocating for precision interventions and addressing disparities in cancer diagnoses and treatment, particularly for high-risk populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: 3D neuronal cultures, schizophrenia modeling, drug discovery, light sheet microscopy, tissue clearing, ketamine effects on dopamine system, midbrain dopamine neurons, single-cell RNA sequencing, and evolutionary biology.

3D neuronal cultures, including brain spheroids and organoids, are explored to enhance in vitro models for brain diseases, particularly schizophrenia, through the Modular Neuronal Network (MoNNet) approach. This method captures neuronal dynamics and network activities, aiding in modeling schizophrenia-related dysfunctions and facilitating drug discovery. Light sheet microscopy advancements focus on improving imaging techniques, such as SPED light sheet microscopy, which allows rapid volumetric imaging of large biological samples like mouse brains and zebrafish. The study of ketamine's effects reveals its impact on dopamine neurons and neural plasticity, contributing to understanding addiction and mental health. Research on midbrain dopamine neurons identifies distinct subpopulations and their wiring to striatal regions, while single-cell RNA sequencing enables the classification of cell types in complex tissues. Lastly, evolutionary biology studies link mesodermal cells in marine annelids to chordate development and examine planktonic larvae for insights into animal life cycle evolution.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: NMR spectroscopy, chemical exchange, spin relaxation, piRNA silencing, neuroprotection, protein disulfide isomerase (PDI), Cadherin dimerization, ribonuclease HI (RNHI) dynamics, molecular dynamics (MD) simulations, and enzyme efficiency.

NMR spectroscopy is utilized to investigate chemical exchange and spin relaxation, with advancements in the Carr-Purcell-Meiboom-Gill (CPMG) experiment and R1_ relaxation techniques. The research on piRNA silencing focuses on Asterix/Gtsf1's role in retrotransposon regulation in germline cells. Neuroprotection studies highlight a small molecule's effects on PDI, showing promise for treating neurodegenerative diseases. The dimerization mechanisms of Cadherin-11 and E-cadherin are explored using NMR, revealing key dynamics in cell adhesion. RNHI dynamics research emphasizes the correlation between enzyme conformational states and activity, supported by MD simulations that assess thermostability and substrate recognition. The findings across these areas illustrate the intricate relationships between molecular dynamics, enzyme function, and therapeutic potential in neurodegeneration and cellular adhesion processes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: observational health data science, machine learning in healthcare, drug safety research, predictive modeling, clinical trial design, and pharmacoepidemiology.

Observational health data science focuses on harmonizing international health data through standardized vocabularies and the OMOP Common Data Model, enabling large-scale research. Machine learning in healthcare includes developing algorithms for semi-automated phenotype evaluation and improving predictive validity in health outcomes. Drug safety research emphasizes the development of resources for adverse drug events and enhancing detection methods using observational data. Predictive modeling involves creating models for patient outcomes, including drug surveillance and treatment patterns in chronic conditions. Clinical trial design explores generalizability metrics to evaluate participant selection strategies and their correlation with adverse events. Pharmacoepidemiology research examines medication adherence in chronic treatments and the impact of drug switching on adherence measures, alongside the prevalence of pharmacogenomic drug exposure in patients, highlighting the need for further investigation into pre-emptive testing strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: curiosity, agency, memory, stress, self-awareness, metacognition, learning from errors, moral decision-making, and cognitive psychology. 

Curiosity is examined through two perspectives: the reinforcement-learning view and the 'need for agency' view, revealing that curiosity motivates individuals to actively seek knowledge rather than passively receive answers. Agency is explored in relation to feelings of control and decision-making, showing that individuals feel more culpable when following orders than when making independent choices. Memory research includes studies on the effects of stress on recall, particularly in high-stress situations like those faced by firefighters, and how self-awareness influences memory monitoring in Alzheimer's patients. Metacognition is investigated through the impact of self-generated errors on recall and the role of mind wandering in learning processes. The interplay between stress and memory highlights the negative effects of stress on episodic memory and willpower. Additionally, the research addresses how cognitive and mood factors influence self-awareness, emphasizing a hierarchical model of memory self-monitoring. Overall, this work contributes to understanding complex cognitive processes across various contexts.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), plasmablastic lymphoma (PBL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), germinal center (GC) B cell dynamics, somatic hypermutation (SHM), class switch recombination (CSR), genetic mutations in B cell lymphomas, epigenetic therapies, and single-cell transcriptomics.

The research extensively investigates DLBCL, focusing on hypermutations in super-enhancers and their impact on oncogenes such as BCL6 and BCL2, identifying potential therapeutic targets. In PBL, the study reveals mutations in the JAK-STAT pathway, highlighting its role in pathogenesis. CLL transformation to Richter syndrome is examined, uncovering mutations in TP53 and NOTCH1. The dynamics of GC B cells are explored, emphasizing immunoglobulin gene editing through SHM and CSR, with findings on heterogeneous subpopulations and their implications for lymphoma development. The research identifies genetic mutations like KMT2D and CREBBP that influence GC expansion and immune signaling. Additionally, it explores the potential of epigenetic therapies targeting CREBBP and EP300, and employs single-cell transcriptomics to enhance understanding of B cell differentiation and lymphoma prognosis. Overall, the studies underscore the complex genetic and epigenetic landscape of B cell lymphomas, informing personalized medicine approaches.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), histological evaluation, acute lung injury (ALI), stem cell therapy, cystic fibrosis, bioengineering of lung grafts, targeted drug delivery, pediatric trauma care, and fluid resuscitation.

The researcher investigates ARDS and its management in patients with concomitant ALL, demonstrating that standard chemotherapy remains effective despite SARS-CoV-2 infection. In histological evaluation, a standardized digital method for assessing ALI is developed to improve accuracy and reproducibility in research. A novel pre-clinical model using swine for ARDS facilitates therapeutic testing, while intratracheal delivery of stem cells is explored for lung injury treatment, focusing on dosage and monitoring. The study also examines the pathological remodeling of the lung matrix in cystic fibrosis and develops functional vascularized lung grafts for bioengineering applications. Additionally, a targeted delivery method for liquid microvolumes into the lung is proposed to enhance drug efficacy. In pediatric trauma care, a Delphi process validates a fluid treatment algorithm, addressing the complexities of intravenous fluid therapy and the debate on resuscitation strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: pediatric critical care, ECMO (extracorporeal membrane oxygenation), machine learning, maternal health, digital health, protein labeling, protein tyrosine kinases, protein engineering, and obstetrics.

Pediatric critical care research focuses on interventions and outcomes for critically ill children, particularly through the Neuro-SPARK scoring system for assessing neurologic injury risk in ECMO patients. ECMO studies include mortality prediction in COVID-19 cohorts and resource allocation using machine learning. Machine learning applications extend to improving clinical decision-making in pediatric critical care. Maternal health research emphasizes digital health platforms to reduce emergency visits, the impact of cesarean delivery trends, and shared decision-making in labor outcomes. Protein labeling studies involve novel methods for high-resolution protein labeling and insights into tyrosine kinases and phosphotyrosine signaling. Protein engineering advancements include split intein technology applications. In obstetrics, research examines the effects of virtual doula appointments on birth outcomes and variability in cesarean delivery rates among healthcare providers, highlighting the influence of nursing care in obstetric practices.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: decision-making, neural mechanisms, evidence accumulation, perceptual judgments, working memory, neural oscillations, and brain resilience. 

Decision-making is a central focus, particularly exploring the neural mechanisms that underpin the processes involved in making choices. The research highlights the role of the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) in evidence accumulation and decision formation, where neurons represent decision variables and maintain continuity even when intervening actions disrupt their linkage. Neural mechanisms related to evidence accumulation are examined, revealing how transient oscillations in the parietal cortex aid in routing evidence during perceptual tasks. The studies also delve into perceptual judgments, showing that individuals can assess task difficulty based on accumulated evidence. Working memory dynamics are explored, emphasizing low-dimensional encoding linked to neural firing rates. Additionally, the research investigates brain resilience, demonstrating how other brain areas can compensate for disruptions in LIP, thus maintaining decision-making capabilities despite focal perturbations. Overall, these findings contribute to a nuanced understanding of the interplay between various neural areas and cognitive functions in decision-making processes.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), cardiovascular biomarkers, single-cell analysis, atherosclerosis, long intergenic non-coding RNAs (lincRNAs), telemedicine in cardiogenetics, and multiomics approaches in cardiovascular disease.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) research focuses on plasma adipokines, proteomics for predicting cardiac death, and transcriptomics profiling of microRNAs to identify biomarkers. Cardiovascular biomarkers are explored through studies on circulating biomarkers and the effects of bariatric surgery. Single-cell analysis investigates cellular heterogeneity in atherosclerosis, utilizing innovative models for RNA sequencing and non-invasive imaging techniques. Atherosclerosis research delves into smooth muscle cell phenotypic switching and therapeutic targets like ADAMTS7. Long intergenic non-coding RNAs (lincRNAs) are studied for their roles in adipogenesis, inflammation, and cardiometabolic diseases, emphasizing tissue specificity. Telemedicine has transformed cardiogenetics, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, addressing recruitment challenges for clinical trials. Finally, multiomics approaches are essential for identifying new drug targets and understanding the genetic and lifestyle factors influencing cardiovascular diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurodevelopmental disorders, psychiatric disorders, autism spectrum disorder (ASD), genetic influences on behavior, neurotransmitter systems, dopamine, serotonin, behavioral interventions, and pediatric psychopharmacology. 

The research delves into neurodevelopmental disorders, utilizing mouse models to explore genetic and neurotransmitter influences on behaviors associated with conditions like obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) and Williams syndrome. It highlights the role of the dopamine system and the impact of the EAAT3 transporter on behaviors linked to amphetamines. In the context of ASD, the researcher investigates genetic variations, such as 16p11.2 copy number variations, and their effects on motor skills and social behavior, emphasizing the complexity of these conditions. The serotonin system's involvement in ASD is also examined, particularly through the study of serotonin transporter variants and their relation to social behaviors. Additionally, the research addresses the challenges of treating psychiatric disorders in children, advocating for specialized treatment approaches and the need for improved training in autism care among healthcare providers. Overall, the research underscores the intricate interplay between genetics, neurotransmitters, and behavioral outcomes in neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cognitive health, cerebrovascular disease, Alzheimer's disease, white matter hyperintensities (WMH), dietary factors, lifestyle factors, neuroimaging, financial stress, sleep patterns, depression, social networks, and aging. 

Cognitive health research focuses on understanding the factors influencing cognitive function in older adults, including the effects of dietary flavanols and multivitamin supplementation. Cerebrovascular disease studies examine the impact of small vessel disease on cognitive outcomes, particularly in Alzheimer's trials. Alzheimer's disease research investigates various mediators of cognitive decline, including genetic factors, subjective cognitive decline, and the role of inflammation. White matter hyperintensities (WMH) are linked to cognitive impairment and neurodegeneration, with studies exploring their relationship with hypertension and sleep quality. Dietary factors, such as vitamin D and prebiotics, are assessed for their potential impact on dementia risk. Lifestyle factors, including social networks and financial stress, are analyzed for their influence on cognitive health. Neuroimaging studies address disparities among populations and the effects of various health conditions on brain structure. Sleep patterns are evaluated for their effects on cognitive performance, while depression and its neuropsychological implications are explored in aging populations.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: neurodegenerative disorders, synaptic function, Alzheimer's disease (AD), cognitive dysfunction, memory impairment, neuroinflammation, tau pathology, amyloid-beta (A_), phosphodiesterase inhibitors, and therapeutic targets.

The research primarily focuses on neurodegenerative disorders, investigating mechanisms that affect synaptic function and memory, particularly in Alzheimer's disease. It highlights the role of dysfunctional mitochondria and tau oligomers in impairing synaptic plasticity and neuronal function. The studies also explore how heart failure leads to cognitive dysfunction through intracellular calcium signaling and the protective effects of specific treatments. Neuroinflammation is examined through the role of p38 MAPK and potential therapeutic interventions, including phosphodiesterase inhibitors that enhance cognitive function. The interplay between amyloid-beta and tau pathology is critically analyzed, challenging existing hypotheses and suggesting new therapeutic strategies. Additionally, the researcher investigates the role of specific receptors and proteins, such as the 5HT2b receptor and FNDC5/irisin, in synaptic plasticity and memory. Overall, the research emphasizes the need for innovative therapeutic approaches targeting these molecular pathways to improve cognitive outcomes in neurodegenerative diseases.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: lipoprotein lipase (LpL) deficiency, dietary fats and cardiovascular health, high-fat diet effects on kidney metabolism, omega-3 fatty acids in disease prevention, intravenous lipid emulsions, and the role of LpL in immune responses.

Lipoprotein lipase (LpL) deficiency is studied for its negative effects on bone marrow myelopoiesis and monocyte levels, crucial for inflammation in metabolic and cardiovascular diseases. The research on dietary fats emphasizes the benefits of n-3 fatty acids in replacing saturated fats to reduce atherosclerosis risk. The impact of high-fat diets on kidney substrate uptake is investigated using ex vivo PET/CT imaging, revealing altered metabolism and potential indicators of diabetic nephropathy. The therapeutic roles of omega-3 fatty acids are explored in cardiovascular and central nervous system diseases, highlighting their mechanisms and contrasting treatment effects. The pharmacokinetics of intravenous lipid emulsions containing medium-chain triglycerides and fish oil are examined for their organ delivery and metabolism in parenteral nutrition. Lastly, LpL's unconventional roles in immune responses and lipid transport are explored, indicating its broader implications in cardiovascular disease and tissue degeneration.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: body composition, skeletal muscle mass, obesity, bariatric surgery, nutrition in heart failure, prenatal exposure to pollutants, gestational weight gain, and advanced body composition measurement techniques. 

Body composition research includes developing prediction models for skeletal muscle mass using DXA and MRI, and investigating its relationship with COVID-19 severity. Studies on obesity focus on the validity of DXA against MRI for estimating visceral adipose tissue in post-bariatric surgery patients and the impact of gestational weight gain on postpartum adipose distribution. Bariatric surgery research examines body composition changes, resting energy expenditure, and the effects of hormonal repletion on muscle efficiency. Nutrition in heart failure highlights the need for specific dietary recommendations and the challenges of multimodal interventions. Prenatal exposure studies investigate the effects of airborne pollutants on childhood growth, while gestational weight gain research emphasizes its link to childhood obesity and the importance of healthy weight strategies. Lastly, advancements in body composition measurement techniques are explored, comparing methods like air displacement plethysmography to dual X-ray absorptiometry for improved accuracy across BMI classifications.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: multiple sclerosis (MS), cognitive impairment, exercise and physical activity, anxiety management, treatment disparities, machine learning, brain connectivity, personality traits, social support, and memory function.

The researcher investigates multiple sclerosis (MS), focusing on cognitive impairment and treatment disparities. They explore how demographic factors like education and sex affect access to disease-modifying therapies (DMTs) and cognitive outcomes. The role of exercise in MS is examined, particularly through randomized controlled trials assessing oral antipyretic treatments to manage overheating during exercise and the effectiveness of telehealth support groups for anxiety reduction. Machine learning techniques are applied to analyze cognitive status and white matter integrity. The research also delves into brain connectivity, revealing alterations linked to memory dysfunction and the impact of personality traits on health outcomes. Social support is highlighted as beneficial for mental health and motor function in MS patients. Additionally, the researcher studies memory function, identifying effective interventions and the effects of external factors like temperature on cognitive performance. Overall, these investigations aim to enhance understanding and treatment of cognitive and emotional challenges faced by individuals with MS.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: kidney-related genetic disorders, congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT), genetic basis of neural tube defects, congenital obstructive uropathy (COU), and genetic diagnostics.

Kidney-related genetic disorders focus on identifying genetic variants associated with conditions like focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome (SRNS), revealing significant genetic associations such as the APOL1 p.N264K variant and CNVs in PLCE1 and NPHS2. CAKUT research emphasizes the genetic landscape, including DSTYK variants and recessive mutations in TRAP1, and highlights the importance of early risk assessment for chronic kidney disease. The genetic basis of neural tube defects investigates the 22q11.2 deletion's role, particularly the Crkl gene, in increasing risks for conditions like meningomyelocele, suggesting maternal folate's mitigating effects. COU research identifies genetic etiology in a subset of cases and advocates for a genetic-first diagnostic approach to improve outcomes. Finally, advancements in genetic diagnostics aim to enhance understanding and management of these complex disorders through innovative multidisciplinary strategies.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cortical proteins, motor resilience, cognitive resilience, depression, cancer genomics, Alzheimer's disease, epigenomics, bioinformatics, and genomic instability. 

Cortical proteins are investigated for their role in promoting motor and cognitive resilience among older adults, with studies identifying specific proteins linked to motor decline and cognitive abilities. Motor resilience focuses on identifying peptides associated with slower motor decline, while cognitive resilience explores mechanisms to differentiate resilience levels in aging populations. Depression research examines transcriptome-wide associations to understand its pathogenesis and develop novel treatments. Cancer genomics encompasses the integrative analysis of mRNA expression and DNA copy number data for gene prioritization, emphasizing the importance of combining genomic profiling techniques. Alzheimer's disease studies identify glycoproteins and genetic factors related to cognitive resilience and epigenomic changes, employing multi-omic approaches to uncover disease mechanisms. Epigenomics research highlights the significance of DNA methylation and histone modifications in understanding neurodegenerative diseases. Bioinformatics contributions include methods for analyzing scRNA-seq data and evaluating differential methylation testing. Lastly, genomic instability research addresses the role of TKI-refractory stem cells in chronic myeloid leukemia, linking them to disease progression.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: picornaviruses, immune response, enteroviruses, Zika virus, neurotropism, poliovirus, rhinoviruses, and public engagement in science. 

Research on picornaviruses focuses on understanding their entry mechanisms and immune responses, particularly addressing knowledge gaps that hinder effective public health strategies. The immune response studies emphasize the roles of RIG-I and MDA5 receptors in detecting viruses like Coxsackievirus B3 and encephalomyocarditis virus, revealing their distinct functions in type I interferon production. The investigation of enteroviruses, specifically nonpoliovirus enteroviruses, highlights their genetic similarities and cross-reactive antibody responses, which are crucial for understanding disease outcomes. Zika virus research uncovers its neurotropism and effects on neurodevelopment, particularly in congenital Zika virus syndrome. The neurotropism of Enterovirus D68 is explored in relation to acute flaccid myelitis, showcasing its ability to infect neural cells. Poliovirus studies identify receptor binding mechanisms, while rhinovirus research differentiates immune responses in human macrophages, revealing distinct pathways linked to asthma exacerbations. Lastly, the importance of public engagement in science is emphasized, advocating for effective communication to bridge gaps between scientists and society.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: Alzheimer's disease (AD), epigenomics, genetic variations, insulin resistance (IR), transcriptomics, neuroticism, multi-omics, multiple sclerosis (MS), DNA methylation, and immune response.

Research on Alzheimer's disease focuses on the interplay between epigenomic features and genetic variations, particularly how certain epigenomic factors related to microglia can influence AD risk in APOE _4 carriers. Studies reveal significant genetic associations and the potential for functional genetic scores to predict AD risk. The investigation of insulin resistance highlights its link to AD through molecular signatures at the CPT1A locus, enhancing understanding of their biological connections. Transcriptomic changes in AD are explored through RNA editing events and the impact of neuroticism on cognitive decline and TAU pathology. Multi-omic approaches are emphasized for capturing AD's complexity, leading to the creation of a comprehensive multi-omic atlas of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. In multiple sclerosis research, the focus is on mapping DNA methylation quantitative trait loci in CD4+ T-cells, identifying loci that influence both MS susceptibility and DNA methylation, thereby providing insights into the epigenomic contributions to this disease.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), aging, inflammation, myelopoiesis, leukemia, metabolic regulation, atherosclerosis, and single-cell analysis.

Hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) are a primary focus, with investigations into their functional states throughout life, particularly the decline in functionality with aging. This decline is linked to metabolic changes, epigenetic alterations, and inflammatory responses. Aging-related inflammation, particularly IL-1 signaling, impacts HSCs, leading to diminished regenerative capacity and skewed differentiation. The study of myelopoiesis reveals that maternal inflammation affects fetal HSCs, limiting their myeloid production. In leukemia, the research explores the role of deregulated signaling pathways and the bone marrow niche's influence on HSC maintenance. Metabolic regulation is essential for HSC function, with autophagy identified as a protective mechanism against stress. Additionally, the researcher investigates atherosclerosis by analyzing the cellular composition of plaques through high-dimensional single-cell multimodal techniques, aiming to clarify the cellular interactions and mechanisms involved in this condition.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: stress and neurotransmitter mechanisms, neurogenesis, depression, motor function in neurological disorders, electroconvulsive therapy (ECT), memory and spatial representation, and in vivo imaging of neuronal activity.

Research on stress and neurotransmitter mechanisms investigates how stress alters fear responses in the brain, impacting behavior and mental health, particularly in anxiety disorders. Neurogenesis studies focus on its role in Alzheimer's disease and major depressive disorder, emphasizing how enhancing neurogenesis can alleviate memory deficits and improve treatment responses. The exploration of motor function in neurological disorders, particularly in Parkinson's disease, examines the loss of GABAergic inhibition and its effects on motor sensitization. ECT research highlights its potential to induce neuroplastic changes, improving mood and cognitive function in severe depression. Memory and spatial representation studies reveal the importance of adult-born granule cells in the dentate gyrus for memory discrimination and spatial processing, as well as strategies to rejuvenate aging memory circuits. Lastly, the in vivo imaging research provides protocols for analyzing neuronal activity in the dorsal raphe nucleus, addressing challenges in surgical procedures and motion correction for accurate data collection.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: obesity, SARS-CoV-2, body weight regulation, high-fat diets, maternal weight awareness, metabolic inflammation, adipose tissue macrophages, energy expenditure, lipid metabolism, cancer metabolism, and immune responses.

Obesity is a central theme, with studies highlighting its role as a significant risk factor for severe COVID-19 outcomes, particularly the correlation between Body Mass Index (BMI) and intubation or mortality. Research on body weight regulation examines how high-fat diets affect food intake and body weight defense mechanisms, revealing non-leptin systems that respond to overfeeding. Maternal weight awareness in pregnant women is explored to assess their understanding of weight-related risks. The impact of obesity-related metabolic inflammation on cardiometabolic health is investigated, focusing on the roles of adipose tissue macrophages (ATMs) and their adaptive functions. The research also delves into energy expenditure in weight-reduced states and identifies novel pathways for lipid release, emphasizing the importance of lysosomal function. Additionally, the interplay between obesity and cancer metabolism is explored, linking lipid utilization in tumors to immune responses, while immune responses are further connected to metabolic disorders through studies on myeloid cell dynamics and oxidative stress.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: psychotropic medication use, schizophrenia, health inequities, adjunctive medications, antipsychotics, treatment-resistant schizophrenia, clozapine, premature mortality, polypharmacy, mental health interventions, self-stigma, late-onset psychoses, adherence to medication, regulatory principles, suicide risk, violence risk, dementia in schizophrenia, aerobic exercise, cognitive training, and metabolic syndrome.

The researcher investigates psychotropic medication use in adults with schizophrenia, focusing on prescription patterns and health inequities. Studies assess the effectiveness of adjunctive medications with antipsychotics and the comparative effectiveness of clozapine for treatment-resistant cases. Premature mortality risks among this population are explored, alongside polypharmacy practices. Mental health interventions include a trial on reducing self-stigma and addressing late-onset psychoses. The researcher also examines adherence to long-acting injectable antipsychotics and proposes regulatory principles for improving drug approval processes. Additionally, suicide and violence risks in schizophrenia are analyzed, with studies on dementia prevalence and aerobic exercise's potential benefits. Cognitive training's impact on outcomes and the relationship between antipsychotic switching and metabolic syndrome are also key areas of focus.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: cervical spinal cord stimulation, unilateral cerebral palsy (UCP), genetic testing in cerebral palsy, contrast sensitivity measurement, motor function recovery, bioelectronics for spinal cord stimulation, and vagus nerve stimulation.

Cervical spinal cord stimulation research indicates that lateral stimulation produces stronger muscle responses than midline stimulation, aiding therapeutic interventions. Studies on UCP reveal anatomical and functional differences based on injury type, with periventricular injuries correlating with better hand function. Genetic testing in CP identifies causative variants, suggesting genetic susceptibility to environmental factors. The Curveball tool measures contrast sensitivity effectively, demonstrating high repeatability. Research on motor function recovery emphasizes the importance of timing in stimulation methods and explores innovative approaches to spinal cord rehabilitation, including vagus nerve stimulation paired with rehabilitation. The development of ester-free bioelectronics showcases advancements in materials for spinal cord stimulation implants, focusing on maintaining performance over time while ensuring safety and efficacy in chronic applications. Overall, this research encompasses a comprehensive exploration of therapeutic strategies for enhancing motor function and recovery in neurological conditions.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: caregiving youth, mental health disorders, cochlear implants, auditory processing, and cochlear mechanics. 

Caregiving youth research focuses on the recognition and challenges faced by young individuals who provide care to adult family members, emphasizing emotional difficulties, academic performance, and health risks, particularly among diverse ethnic groups. Mental health disorder studies explore various aspects, including the efficacy of internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy (iCBT) for major depressive disorder, the role of GABA in PTSD, and the influence of sex on placebo effects in pain management. Cochlear implant research encompasses advancements in implantable technologies, such as novel microphones and sensors for improved auditory reception, and surgical techniques for electrode insertion. Auditory processing studies investigate sound transmission dynamics in the middle ear and the impact of muscle contractions on acoustics. Lastly, cochlear mechanics research delves into the nonlinear behaviors of cochlear structures, the effects of pharmacological agents on cochlear function, and the development of methodologies for enhanced auditory analysis, contributing to a comprehensive understanding of hearing mechanisms.

This researcher's research directions can be categorized into the following atomic topics and fields: virology, protein evolution, microbiome interactions, synthetic biology, bacterial genome engineering, and computational modeling. 

In virology, the researcher investigates SARS-CoV-2 variants, focusing on their susceptibility to neutralization and immune evasion, particularly the Omicron subvariants BA.2.87.1 and BA.2.86. Findings indicate BA.2.87.1 has a lower public health risk due to reduced infectivity despite immune evasion. The study of protein evolution reveals limits on divergence over billions of years, emphasizing structural conservation and mutation fitness effects. 

Research on microbiome interactions highlights the role of Th17 cells in regulating mucosal homeostasis and the pathogenicity of Fusobacterium nucleatum in periodontal disease and colorectal cancer. In synthetic biology, the researcher explores metagenomic mining for gene expression regulation and programmable gene circuits. 

Bacterial genome engineering advances include CRISPR-based methods for precise genetic modifications and the development of engineered biocomposites. Lastly, computational modeling integrates experimental data to predict microbial community dynamics, enhancing understanding of ecosystem functions.
